Int'l MacroEcon 笔记

发表于 2023-09-06 分类于 经济 本文字数： 17k 阅读时长 ≈ 55 分钟

本文是国际宏观经济学的笔记，教材是「International Macroeconomics: A Modern Approach」

L1 - Introduction

Positive vs. Normative

  • Positive economics: How does the world work?
  • Normative economics: How should the world work?

Balance of Payments Accounts

Current Account (CA)

  • CA records exports and imports of G&S, int'l receipts and payments of income.
  • (+) -> exports, income receipts
  • (-) -> imports, income payments

Current Account Balance

  • Trade Balance
    • Merchandise Trade Balance: NX of goods
    • Service Balances: NX of services
  • Income Balance
    • Net Investment Income: interests, diidends
    • Net International Compensation to Employees: compensation to (domestic workers abroad - foreign workers)
  • Net Unilateral Transfers
    • Personal Remittances
    • Government Transfers

Financial Account (FA)

  • changes in a country's net foreign asset position.
  • (+) -> Sell assets to foreigners
  • (-) -> buy assets from abroad

Financial Account Balance

  • Increase in Foreign-Owned Assets in Home Country - Increase in Home-Owned Assets Abroad
  • Assets include: Securities, Currencies, Bank loans, Foreign direct investment (FDI)

Fundamental Balance-of-Payments Identity

  • CA Balance = -(FA Balance)

Capital Account

  • 3rd account besides CA and FA
  • Records international transfers of financial capital
    • debt forgiveness
    • migrants' transfers
  • Not discussed in this course

CA/FA Balance Practice

(a) An Australian resident buys a smartphone from South Korea for $500

Answer: CA = -500, FA = +500 (import goods)

(b) An Italian friend comes to Australia and stays at Plaza Hotel paying for $400 with his Italian VISA card.

Answer: CA = +400, FA = -400 (export serices)

(c) Australian government send $700 medicines to an African country affected by epidemic.

Answer: CA = 700 - 700 = 0, FA = 0 (unilateral transfer)

Reason: CA +700 (export goods); CA -700 (gives up receiving money)

(d) An Australian resident purchases shares from FIAT Italy with AUD.

Answer: CA = 0; FA = -400 + 400 = 0

Reason: FA -400 (buy shares from abroad); FA +400 (sell AUD to FIAT Italy)

Net International Investment Position (NIIP)

NIIP = A - L

  • A -> foreign assets held by home residents
  • L -> home assets held by foreigners

A CA deficit implies that the country has to

  • Reduce A (int'l asset position)
  • Increase L (int'l liability position)

Valuation changes: prices of financial instruments (currency, stock, bond) can change

ΔNIIP = CA + Valuation Changes

Valuation Changes Example

International assets:

  • 25 shares of Italian carmaker Fiat
  • 2 € per share
  • 2 AUD per €

International liabilities:

  • 80 Australian bonds held by foreigners
  • 1 AUD per unit

NIIP = A - L = 25 · 2 · 2 - 80 · 1 = 20 AUD

【Event 1】Euro depreciates to 1 AUD per €

  • NIIP = A - L = 25 · 2 · 1 - 80 = -30 AUD

【Event 2】Share price of Fiat increases to 7 € per share

  • NIIP = A - L = 25 · 7 · 1 - 80 = 95 AUD

NIIP Practice

The question is about balance of payments of US. Exchange rate is EUR/USD = 1.5

Question 1

  • US starts 2023 with 100 shares of Volkswagen (1 EUR/share)
  • RW holds 200 units of US government bonds (2 USD/unit)
  • Calculate NIIPUSNIIP^{US}NIIPUS

Answer 1

  • AUSA^{US}AUS = 100 · 1 · 1.5 = 150 USD
  • LUSL^{US}LUS = 200 · 2 = 400 USD
  • NIIPUS=AUS−LUSNIIP^{US}=A^{US}-L^{US}NIIPUS=AUS−LUS = -250 USD

Question 2

  • US 2023 exports: Toys (7 USD)
  • US 2023 imports: Shirts (9 EUR)
  • Rate of return on Volkswagen shares: 5%
  • Rate of return on Outlandian bonds: 1%
  • US residents received 3 EUR from relatives living abroad
  • US government donated 4 USD to a hospital in Africa
  • Calculate TB, NII, Net Unilateral Transfers, CA, NIIP

Answer 2

  • TB = 7 - 1.5 · 9 = -6.5 USD
  • NII (Income Balance) = 0.05 · 100 · 1.5 - 0.01 · 400 = 3.5 USD
  • Net Unilateral Transfers = 3 · 1.5 - 4 = 0.5 USD
  • Current Account = -6.5 + 3.5 + 0.5 = -2.5 USD
  • NIIP = -250 - 2.5 = -252.5 USD

L2.1 - NIIP-NII-Paradox

If no valuation changes: NIIPt=(CAt+⋯+CA1)+NIIP0NIIP_{t}=(CA_{t}+\dots+CA_{1})+NIIP_{0}NIIPt​=(CAt​+⋯+CA1​)+NIIP0​

NII and NIIP in the US

  • NIIP < 0 (largest external debtor)
  • NII > 0 (receives more investment income)

Dark Matter Hypothesis

NIIP > 0, but the BEA fails to account for all of it

  • BEA -> Bureau of Economic Analysis (US)

Hypothesis:

  • U.S. FDI contains intangible capital (e.g. brand capital)
  • intangible capital not reflected in NIIP, but recorded in NII
  • Therefore, NIIP < 0 and NII > 0

Validation:

  • TNIIP (true NIIP) = NIIP + Dark Matter
    • NIIP = observed NIIP (-$11.1T in 2020)
    • NII = net investment income ($0.1909T in 2020)
    • r = interest rate on net foreign assets (0.05)
    • NII = r · TNIIP
  • TNIIP = NII / r = $3.818T
  • Dark Matter = TNIIP - NIIP = $14.9T
  • It's unlikely for $14.9T to go unnoticed by BEA

Return Differentials

Hypothesis:

  • A -> risky, high-return assets (foreign equity and FDI)
  • L -> safer, low-return assets (US government bonds, T-bills)
  • Let: rAr^{A}rA (return on A), rLr^{L}rL (return on L)
  • If interest rate differential rA−rL>0r^{A}-r^{L}\gt 0rA−rL>0, then NIIP < 0 and NII > 0

Validation:

  • NII=rAA−rLLNII=r^{A}A-r^{L}LNII=rAA−rLL
    • A = $32.2T
    • L = $46.3T
    • rLr^{L}rL = 0.37%
    • NII = $0.1909T
  • Therefore, rAr^{A}rA = 1.12%, rA−rLr^{A}-r^{L}rA−rL = 0.75%
  • This is more plausible than Dark Matter Hypothesis

Flipped NIIP-NII-Paradox

NIIPUS=AUS−LUS=LRW−ARW=−NIIPRWNIIP^{US}=A^{US}-L^{US}=L^{RW}-A^{RW}=-NIIP^{RW}NIIPUS=AUS−LUS=LRW−ARW=−NIIPRW

NIIUS=rAAUS−rLLUS=rALRW−rLARW=−NIIRWNII^{US}=r^{A}A^{US}-r^{L}L^{US}=r^{A}L^{RW}-r^{L}A^{RW}=-NII^{RW}NIIUS=rAAUS−rLLUS=rALRW−rLARW=−NIIRW

The rest of the world (RW) must experience a flipped paradox: NIIPRWNIIP^{RW}NIIPRW > 0 and NIIRWNII^{RW}NIIRW < 0

  • e.g. China

L2.2 - CA Sustainability

CA surplus and deficit

  • CA surplus (pay < receive): CN, DE, JP
  • CA deficit (pay > receive): US, UK

Perpetual Trade Balance (TB)

  • NO: initial NIIP < 0 (debtor)
    • need TB surplus to service its debt
  • YES: initial NIIP > 0
    • finance the deficit with interests from net investments abroad

Perpetual TB Deficit Analysis

Rules:

  • The economy lasts for only two periods, periods 1 and 2.
  • The interest rate r on investments held for one period is exogenously given
  • Further assumptions:
    • no international compensation to employees
    • no unilateral transfers
    • no valuation changes of assets in this world

Notation:

  • TB1TB_{1}TB1​: Trade balance in period 1
  • CA1CA_{1}CA1​: Current account balance in period 1
  • B0B_{0}B0​: The country's NIIP at the beginning of period 1
  • B1B_{1}B1​: The country's NIIP at the end of period 1

From definition:

  • CA1=TB1+rB0CA_{1}=TB_{1}+rB_{0}CA1​=TB1​+rB0​ (CA balance definition, Assumptions 1 & 2)
  • CA1=B1−B0CA_{1}=B_{1}-B_{0}CA1​=B1​−B0​ (ΔNIIP definition, Assumption 3)

We can dirive:

  • B1=(1+r)B0+TB1B_{1}=(1+r)B_{0}+TB_{1}B1​=(1+r)B0​+TB1​
  • B2=(1+r)B1+TB2B_{2}=(1+r)B_{1}+TB_{2}B2​=(1+r)B1​+TB2​

We can get B0=B2(1+r)2−TB1(1+r)−TB2(1+r)2B_{0}=\frac{B_{2}}{(1+r)^{2}}-\frac{TB_{1}}{(1+r)}-\frac{TB_{2}}{(1+r)^{2}}B0​=(1+r)2B2​​−(1+r)TB1​​−(1+r)2TB2​​

Transversality Condition

  • Let T denote the terminal date of the economy, then BT=0B_{T} = 0BT​=0
  • If BT<0B_{T} \lt 0BT​<0, RW can't collect debt from the country
  • If BT>0B_{T} \gt 0BT​>0, the country can't collect debt from RW
  • In this analysis, B2=0B_{2} = 0B2​=0

Given Transversality Condition:

  • B0=−TB1(1+r)−TB2(1+r)2B_{0}=-\frac{TB_{1}}{(1+r)}-\frac{TB_{2}}{(1+r)^{2}}B0​=−(1+r)TB1​​−(1+r)2TB2​​
  • If B0>0B_{0} \gt 0B0​>0, it's possible to have TB1<0TB_{1} \lt 0TB1​<0 and TB2<0TB_{2} \lt 0TB2​<0
  • If B0<0B_{0} \lt 0B0​<0, it must be TB1>0TB_{1} \gt 0TB1​>0 or TB2>0TB_{2} \gt 0TB2​>0

Since NIIPUS<0NIIP^{US} \lt 0NIIPUS<0 currently, it will have to run TB surplus in the future.

Perpetual CA Deficit Analysis

Same rules from Perpetual TB Deficit Analysis

We had already derived:

  • CA1=B1−B0CA_{1}=B_{1}-B_{0}CA1​=B1​−B0​ (ΔNIIP definition, Assumption 3)
  • CA2=B2−B1CA_{2}=B_{2}-B_{1}CA2​=B2​−B1​ (same reasoning)

We can get:

  • B0=−CA1−CA2+B2B_{0}=-CA_{1}-CA_{2}+B_{2}B0​=−CA1​−CA2​+B2​

Transversality Condition (B2=0B_{2}=0B2​=0):

  • B0=−CA1−CA2B_{0}=-CA_{1}-CA_{2}B0​=−CA1​−CA2​
  • If B0>0B_{0} \gt 0B0​>0, it's possible to have CA1<0CA_{1} \lt 0CA1​<0 and CA2<0CA_{2} \lt 0CA2​<0
  • If B0<0B_{0} \lt 0B0​<0, it must be CA1>0CA_{1} \gt 0CA1​>0 or CA2>0CA_{2} \gt 0CA2​>0

Since NIIPUSNIIP^{US}NIIPUS < 0 currently, it will have to run CA surplus in the future.

Four ways of viewing CA

CA as Changes in NIIP

  • CAt=Bt−Bt−1CA_{t}=B_{t}-B_{t-1}CAt​=Bt​−Bt−1​
  • Notations:
    • CAtCA_{t}CAt​: The country's current account in period t
    • BtB_{t}Bt​: The country's NIIP at the end of period t
  • If CAt<0CA_{t} \lt 0CAt​<0, NIIP falls
  • If CAt>0CA_{t} \gt 0CAt​>0, NIIP rises

CA as Reflections of TB and NII

  • CAt=TBt+rBt−1CA_{t}=TB_{t}+rB_{t-1}CAt​=TBt​+rBt−1​
  • Notation:
    • TBtTB_{t}TBt​: The country's trade balance in period t
    • rrr: The interest rate on investments held for one period
  • This is the original definition of CA

CA as the Gap Between Savings and Investment

  • CAt=St−ItCA_{t}=S_{t}-I_{t}CAt​=St​−It​

CA as the Gap between National Income and Domestic Absorption

  • CAt=Yt−AtCA_{t}=Y_{t}-A_{t}CAt​=Yt​−At​
  • Note: domestic absorption At≡Ct+It+GtA_{t}\equiv C_{t}+I_{t}+G_{t}At​≡Ct​+It​+Gt​

Perpetual TB Deficits (Infinite Economy)

Time periods t=1,2,…t = 1, 2, \ldotst=1,2,…

The interest rate r(>0)r (> 0)r(>0) on investments held for one period is constant over time

As before B1=(1+r)B0+TB1B_1 = (1 + r)B_0 + TB_1B1​=(1+r)B0​+TB1​, and thus B0=B11+r−TB11+rB_0 = \frac{B_1}{1 + r} - \frac{TB_1}{1 + r}B0​=1+rB1​​−1+rTB1​​

Generalizing, for all t≥1t \geq 1t≥1, Bt−1=Bt1+r−TBt1+rB_{t-1} = \frac{B_t}{1 + r} - \frac{TB_t}{1 + r}Bt−1​=1+rBt​​−1+rTBt​​

Therefore, repeatedly using (13), for all T≥1T \geq 1T≥1,

B0=B11+r−TB1(1+r)B_0 = \frac{B_1}{1 + r} - \frac{TB_1}{(1 + r)}B0​=1+rB1​​−(1+r)TB1​​

B0=B2(1+r)2−TB11+r−TB2(1+r)2B_0 = \frac{B_2}{(1 + r)^2} - \frac{TB_1}{1 + r} - \frac{TB_2}{(1 + r)^2}B0​=(1+r)2B2​​−1+rTB1​​−(1+r)2TB2​​

B0=B3(1+r)3−TB11+r−TB2(1+r)2−TB3(1+r)3B_0 = \frac{B_3}{(1 + r)^3} - \frac{TB_1}{1 + r} - \frac{TB_2}{(1 + r)^2} - \frac{TB_3}{(1 + r)^3}B0​=(1+r)3B3​​−1+rTB1​​−(1+r)2TB2​​−(1+r)3TB3​​

B0=BT(1+r)T−TB11+r−…−TBT(1+r)TB_0 = \frac{B_T}{(1 + r)^T} - \frac{TB_1}{1 + r} - \ldots - \frac{TB_T}{(1 + r)^T}B0​=(1+r)TBT​​−1+rTB1​​−…−(1+r)TTBT​​ (14)

Assuming the transversality condition: lim⁡T→∞BT(1+r)T=0\lim_{T \to \infty} \frac{B_T}{(1 + r)^T} = 0limT→∞​(1+r)TBT​​=0

Taking limits on both sides of (14) yields: B0=−∑t=1∞TBt(1+r)tB_0 = - \sum_{t=1}^{\infty} \frac{TB_t}{(1 + r)^t}B0​=−∑t=1∞​(1+r)tTBt​​ (15)

We obtain the same conclusion as in the 2-period case:

  • If B0>0B_0 > 0B0​>0, it is possible (but not necessary) to have TBt<0TB_t < 0TBt​<0 for all t≥1t \geq 1t≥1
  • If B0<0B_0 < 0B0​<0, we must have TBt>0TB_t > 0TBt​>0 for some t≥1t \geq 1t≥1

A country can run a perpetual trade deficit only if the country has positive initial NIIP

Perpetual CA Deficits (Infinite Economy)

We will show that in contrast to finite horizon economies, in infinite horizon economies perpetual CA deficits can be possible even if the country has a negative initial NIIP

We give the example of an economy that is growing and dedicates a growing amount of resources to pay interest on its external debt

Suppose that:

  • B0<0B_0 < 0B0​<0
  • r>0r > 0r>0
  • α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1)
  • TBt=−αrBt−1TB_t = -\alpha rB_{t-1}TBt​=−αrBt−1​ (whenever Bt−1<0B_{t-1} < 0Bt−1​<0 the country generates a TB surplus that suffices to cover a fraction α\alphaα of its interest obligations)

Then Bt=(1+r)Bt−1+TBt−1=(1+r−αr)Bt−1<0, for all t≥1B_t = (1 + r)B_{t-1} + TB_{t-1} = (1 + r - \alpha r) B_{t-1} < 0, \text{ for all } t \geq 1Bt​=(1+r)Bt−1​+TBt−1​=(1+r−αr)Bt−1​<0, for all t≥1 (16)

  • (1+r−αr)>0(1 + r - \alpha r) > 0(1+r−αr)>0
  • NIIP is negative in all periods

Moreover, CAt=rBt−1+TBt=r(1−α)Bt−1<0, for all t≥1CA_t = rB_{t-1} + TB_t = r(1 - \alpha)B_{t-1} < 0, \text{ for all } t \geq 1CAt​=rBt−1​+TBt​=r(1−α)Bt−1​<0, for all t≥1

  • r(1−α)>0r(1 - \alpha) > 0r(1−α)>0
  • Bt−1<0B_{t-1} < 0Bt−1​<0
  • the country runs a perpetual CA deficit

(16) implies that for all t≥1,Bt=(1+r−αr)tB0t \geq 1, B_t = (1 + r - \alpha r)^t B_0t≥1,Bt​=(1+r−αr)tB0​

Thus, the transversality condition is satisfied:

Bt(1+r)t=(1+r−αr1+r)tB0→0\frac{B_t}{(1 + r)^t} = \left(\frac{1 + r - \alpha r}{1 + r}\right)^t B_0 \to 0(1+r)tBt​​=(1+r1+r−αr​)tB0​→0 as t→∞t \to \inftyt→∞

For all t≥1,TBt=−αrBt−1=−αr(1+r−αr)t−1B0>0t \geq 1, TB_t = -\alpha rB_{t-1} = -\alpha r(1 + r - \alpha r)^{t-1} B_0 > 0t≥1,TBt​=−αrBt−1​=−αr(1+r−αr)t−1B0​>0, therefore, the trade balance grows unboundedly over time

Since TBt=Xt−IMt=Qt−Ct−It−Gt=Qt−AtTB_t = X_t - IM_t = Q_t - C_t - I_t - G_t = Q_t - A_tTBt​=Xt​−IMt​=Qt​−Ct​−It​−Gt​=Qt​−At​ and At=Ct+It+Gt≥0A_t = C_t + I_t + G_t \geq 0At​=Ct​+It​+Gt​≥0, the GDP QtQ_tQt​ must grow unboundedly over time, as well.

L3 - CA Determination

Optimal Intertemporal Allocation

  • makes intertemporal consumption and saving decisions
  • smoothes consumption over time by borrowing and lending

Intertemporal Budget Constraint

Rules:

  • Two-period small open economy: periods 1 and 2
  • The single consumption good in the economy is perishable
    • cannot be stored across periods
  • The single asset traded in the financial market is a bond
    • measured in units of the consumption good
  • There is a single representative household (HH) in the economy endowed with
    • B0B_{0}B0​ units of the bond at the beginning of period 1
    • Q1Q_{1}Q1​ units of the good in period 1
    • Q2Q_{2}Q2​ units of the good in period 2
  • Interest Rates:
    • r0r_{0}r0​ for the initial bond holdings
    • r1r_{1}r1​ for the bonds held at the end of period 1
  • The HH can reallocate resources between periods by purchasing or selling bonds (via international financial market)
    • Bt=NIIPB_{t}=NIIPBt​=NIIP

The HH's budget constraint in period 1 is:

  • C1+B1=(1+r0)B0+Q1C_{1}+B_{1}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}C1​+B1​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​
  • Notations:
    • C1C_{1}C1​ is consumption in period 1
    • B1B_{1}B1​ is the amount of bonds held at the end of period 1

The HH's budget constraint in period 2 is:

  • C2+B2=(1+r1)B1+Q2C_{2}+B_{2}=(1+r_{1})B_{1}+Q_{2}C2​+B2​=(1+r1​)B1​+Q2​
  • Note: B2=0B_{2}=0B2​=0 (transversality condition)

By combining the above, we obtain the HH's intertemporal budget constraint. The intertemporal budget constraint describes the consumption paths (C1,C2)(C_{1}, C_{2})(C1​,C2​) that the HH can (just) afford.

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1+Q21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}} =(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}+\frac{Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​+1+r1​Q2​​ (Consumption Values = Initial Assets + Total Income Values)

The slope of the budget constraint is −(1+r1)-(1+r_{1})−(1+r1​)

Utility and Indifference Curves

The utility function U(C1,C2)U(C_{1}, C_{2})U(C1​,C2​) can be represented by indifference curves (ICs).

Common Utility Functions

  • Logarithmic: U(C1,C2)=ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2U(C_{1},C_{2})=\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2}U(C1​,C2​)=lnC1​+lnC2​
  • Square-root: U(C1,C2)=C1+C2U(C_{1},C_{2})={\sqrt{C_{1}}}+{\sqrt{C_{2}}}U(C1​,C2​)=C1​​+C2​​
  • Cobb-Douglas: U(C1,C2)=(C1)α(C2)1−αU(C_{1},C_{2})=(C_{1})^{\alpha}(C_{2})^{1-\alpha}U(C1​,C2​)=(C1​)α(C2​)1−α where (0<α<1)(0\lt \alpha\lt 1)(0<α<1)

Properties of Indifference Curves

  • ICs do not intersect
  • ICs are downward sloping
    • True if more is better
  • The right-upper ICs indicate higher levels of utility
  • ICs have a bowed-in shape towards the origin (convex toward the origin)

Slope of Indifference Curves (MRS)

MRS=U1(C1,C2)U2(C1,C2){\mathrm{MRS}}={\frac{U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})}{U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})}}MRS=U2​(C1​,C2​)U1​(C1​,C2​)​, where:

  • U1(C1,C2)=∂U(C1,C2)∂C1U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{\partial U(C_{1},C_{2})}{\partial C_{1}}U1​(C1​,C2​)=∂C1​∂U(C1​,C2​)​
  • U2(C1,C2)=∂U(C1,C2)∂C2U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{\partial U(C_{1},C_{2})}{\partial C_{2}}U2​(C1​,C2​)=∂C2​∂U(C1​,C2​)​

Slope of IC containing (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​) at (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​) is −U1(C1,C2)U2(C1,C2)-{\frac{U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})}{U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})}}−U2​(C1​,C2​)U1​(C1​,C2​)​

Optimal Intertemporal Allocation

The HH maximizes utility subject to the intertemporal budget constraint.

The optimal consumption path is point B.

At the optimal bundle (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​) the IC is tangent to the intertemporal budget constraint (IBC)

−U1(C1,C2)U2(C1,C2)=−(1+r1)-{\frac{U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})}{U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})}}=-(1+r_{1})−U2​(C1​,C2​)U1​(C1​,C2​)​=−(1+r1​)

or equivalently, U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)

TB and CA in Equilibrium

Exogenously given are r0r_{0}r0​, B0B_{0}B0​, r∗r^{*}r∗, Q1Q_{1}Q1​ and Q2Q_{2}Q2​. An equilibrium is a consumption path (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​) and an interest rate r1r_{1}r1​ such that:

  • Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation
    • C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1+Q21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}} =(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}+\frac{Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​+1+r1​Q2​​
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_{1}=r^{*}r1​=r∗ (free capital mobility)

In this economy, TB1=Q1−C1TB_{1}=Q_{1}-C_{1}TB1​=Q1​−C1​, TB2=Q2−C2TB_{2}=Q_{2}-C_{2}TB2​=Q2​−C2​

And CA1=r0B0+TB1CA_{1}=r_{0}B_{0}+TB_{1}CA1​=r0​B0​+TB1​, B1=B0+CA1B_{1}=B_{0}+CA_{1}B1​=B0​+CA1​, CA2=r1B1+TB2CA_{2}=r_{1}B_{1}+TB_{2}CA2​=r1​B1​+TB2​

Also, since we don't have investments in this economy (I1=I2=0)(I_{1}=I_{2}=0)(I1​=I2​=0), S1=CA1S_{1}=CA_{1}S1​=CA1​, S2=CA2S_{2}=CA_{2}S2​=CA2​

Therefore, the HH's willingness to save determines the TB and CA

Temporary Output Shock

Budget Constraint and Optimal Allocation

  • C1C_{1}C1​ and C2C_{2}C2​ are normal goods (their consumption increases with income)
  • Output in Period 1 = Q1−ΔQ_{1}-\DeltaQ1​−Δ
  • Output in Period 2 = Q2Q_{2}Q2​
  • A is the old and A′ the new endowment point
  • B is the old and B′ the new optimal consumption path
  • C1C_{1}C1​ declines by less than ∆
  • TB1TB_{1}TB1​ deteriorates

Summary

  • Relatively small effect on the consumption path (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​)
  • Temporary negative income shocks are smoothed out by borrowing from the rest of the world
  • Generally, one should expect the borrowing to move the country's trade balance and current account significantly

Permanent Output Shock

Budget Constraint and Optimal Allocation

  • Output in Period 1 = Q1−ΔQ_{1}-\DeltaQ1​−Δ
  • Output in Period 2 = Q2−ΔQ_{2}-\DeltaQ2​−Δ
  • A is the old and A′ the new endowment point
  • B is the old and B′ the new optimal consumption path
  • TB1TB_{1}TB1​ doesn't change much

Summary

  • Relatively large effect on the consumption path (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​)
  • Generally, one should expect permanent negative income shocks to lead to similarly sized reductions in C1C_{1}C1​ and C2C_{2}C2​
  • Generally, one should expect the country's trade balance and current account to not be much affected

Terms of Trade Shocks

Consider an economy which exports endowments of oil (Q1,Q2)(Q_{1},Q_{2})(Q1​,Q2​) and imports food for consumption (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​)

Then, the HH's budget constraints for period 1 and 2 are:

  • C1+B1=(1+r0)B0+TT1Q1C_{1}+B_{1}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+TT_{1}Q_{1}C1​+B1​=(1+r0​)B0​+TT1​Q1​
  • C2=(1+r1)B1+TT2Q2C_{2}=(1+r_{1})B_{1}+TT_{2}Q_{2}C2​=(1+r1​)B1​+TT2​Q2​

Terms of Trade (TT) are the relative price of exports in terms of imports:

  • TT1=P1XP1MTT_{1}=\frac{P_{1}^{X}}{P_{1}^{M}}TT1​=P1M​P1X​​
  • TT2=P2XP2MTT_{2}=\frac{P_{2}^{X}}{P_{2}^{M}}TT2​=P2M​P2X​​

With Terms of Trade Shocks, equlibrium would be:

  • Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation (with TT1TT_1TT1​ and TT2TT_2TT2​)
    • C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+TT1Q1+TT2Q21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}} =(1+r_{0})B_{0}+TT_1 Q_{1}+\frac{TT_2 Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+TT1​Q1​+1+r1​TT2​Q2​​
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_{1}=r^{*}r1​=r∗ (free capital mobility)

Capital Controls

CA deficits are often viewed as bad for a country.

Assume the country's authority introduces a policy that prohibits borrowing, that is, requires B1B_{1}B1​ ≥ 0

Result:

  • The HH can't borrow
  • The optimal allocation moves from B to A (IC is lower)
  • Optimal consumption path changes to:
    • C1=Q1C_{1}=Q_{1}C1​=Q1​
    • C2=Q2C_{2}=Q_{2}C2​=Q2​
  • TB1=TB2=0TB_{1}=TB_{2}=0TB1​=TB2​=0 (TBt=Qt−Ct)(TB_{t}=Q_{t}-C_{t})(TBt​=Qt​−Ct​)

Logarithmic Utility Equilibrium

U(C1,C2)=ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2U(C_{1},C_{2})=\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2}U(C1​,C2​)=lnC1​+lnC2​

Using derivatibe formula dln⁡(x)dx=1x\frac{d\ln(x)}{dx}=\frac{1}{x}dxdln(x)​=x1​, we get:

U1(C1,C2)=∂U(C1,C2)∂C1=∂(ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2)∂C1=1C1U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{\partial U(C_{1},C_{2})}{\partial C_{1}}=\frac{\partial(\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2})}{\partial C_{1}}=\frac{1}{C_{1}}U1​(C1​,C2​)=∂C1​∂U(C1​,C2​)​=∂C1​∂(lnC1​+lnC2​)​=C1​1​

U2(C1,C2)=∂U(C1,C2)∂C2=∂(ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2)∂C2=1C2U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{\partial U(C_{1},C_{2})}{\partial C_{2}}=\frac{\partial(\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2})}{\partial C_{2}}=\frac{1}{C_{2}}U2​(C1​,C2​)=∂C2​∂U(C1​,C2​)​=∂C2​∂(lnC1​+lnC2​)​=C2​1​

Therefore, the equilibrium condition U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​) becomes 1C1=(1+r1)1C2{\frac{1}{C_{1}}}=(1+r_{1}){\frac{1}{C_{2}}}C1​1​=(1+r1​)C2​1​

From the above, we can derive C2=(1+r1)C1C_{2}=(1+r_{1})C_{1}C2​=(1+r1​)C1​

By substituting into Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation, we get:

C1=12[(1+r0)B0+Q1+Q21+r1]C_{1}={\frac{1}{2}}[(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}+{\frac{Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}}]C1​=21​[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​+1+r1​Q2​​]

C2=12(1+r1)[(1+r0)B0+Q1+Q21+r1]C_{2}={\frac{1}{2}(1+r_{1})}[(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}+{\frac{Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}}]C2​=21​(1+r1​)[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​+1+r1​Q2​​]

L4.1 - Int. R. Shocks & Tariffs in an Endowment Economy

World Interest Rate Shocks

World interest rate increase from r∗r^{*}r∗ to r∗+Δr^{*}+\Deltar∗+Δ

HH as debtor

HH as creditor

Substitution effect (SE)

  • An increase in the interest rate makes C1C_{1}C1​ relatively more expensive and C2C_{2}C2​ relatively cheaper
  • Change in period 1 consumption C1C_{1}C1​ due to change in relative "price"
    • A=(C1A,C2A)A=(C_{1}^{A},C_{2}^{A})A=(C1A​,C2A​) = originally optimal path
    • B=(C1B,C2B)B=(C_{1}^{B},C_{2}^{B})B=(C1B​,C2B​) = path that is optimal given budget line that passes through A and has slope (−1+r∗+Δ){(-1+r^{*}+\Delta)}(−1+r∗+Δ)
    • SE=C1B−C1A<0SE=C_{1}^{B}-C_{1}^{A}\lt 0SE=C1B​−C1A​<0
  • Saving in period 1 becomes more attractive

Income effect (IE)

  • Change in C1 due to change in purchasing power
    • B=(C1B,C2B)B=(C_{1}^{B},C_{2}^{B})B=(C1B​,C2B​) = previous path
    • C=(C1C,C2C)C=(C_{1}^{C},C_{2}^{C})C=(C1C​,C2C​) = new optimal path
    • IE=C1C−C1BIE=C_{1}^{C}-C_{1}^{B}IE=C1C​−C1B​
  • r∗r^{*}r∗ ↑ has two opposing effects on HH's purchasing power
    • The HH can purchase more on a fixed budget since the “price” 11+r∗\frac{1}{1+r^{*}}1+r∗1​ of C2C_{2}C2​ falls
    • The present value Q21+r∗\frac{Q_{2}}{1+r^{*}}1+r∗Q2​​ of endowment Q2Q_{2}Q2​ decreases
  • Netting these effect, r∗r^{*}r∗ ↑ makes
    • debtors (for whom Q1<C1Q_{1}\lt C_{1}Q1​<C1​ and thus Q2<C2Q_{2}\lt C_{2}Q2​<C2​) poorer
    • creditors (for whom C1<Q1C_{1}\lt Q_{1}C1​<Q1​ and thus C2<Q2C_{2}\lt Q_{2}C2​<Q2​) richer
  • Since C1C_{1}C1​ is a normal good
    • IE < 0 if purchasing power decreases (debtor)
    • IE > 0 if purchasing power increases (creditor)

TE (total effect) = SE + IE

Int. R. Shocks Summary

Overall, if the interest rate increases:

  • If the country is a debtor (Q1<C1)(Q_{1}\lt C_{1})(Q1​<C1​):
    • IE < 0 as budget line shift that determines IE is to the left.
    • TE = SE + IE < 0 as SE < 0 and IE < 0.
    • Therefore, HH's savings increase after the shock.
  • If the country is a creditor (Q1>C1)(Q_{1}\gt C_{1})(Q1​>C1​):
    • It remains a creditor after the interest rate rise (by a revealed preference argument).
    • IE > 0 as budget line shift that determines IE is to the right.
    • TE = SE + IE (> or <) 0 depending on which of SE and IE dominates.

Import Tariffs

Given two-goods economy:

  • exports endowments of oil (Q1,Q2)(Q_{1},Q_{2})(Q1​,Q2​)
  • imports food for consumption (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​)
  • The HH treats τt\tau_{t}τt​ and LtL_{t}Lt​ as exogeneously given

Assume that in each period t ∈ {1, 2}, the government

  • imposes an import tariff τt≥0\tau_{t}\geq0τt​≥0, and
  • returns the revenue from τt\tau_{t}τt​ via a lump-sum transfer LtL_{t}Lt​

Then, the HH's budget constraints for period 1 and 2 are:

(1+τ1)C1+B1=(1+r0)B0+TT1Q1+L1(1+\tau_{1})C_{1}+B_{1}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+TT_{1}Q_{1}+L_{1}(1+τ1​)C1​+B1​=(1+r0​)B0​+TT1​Q1​+L1​

(1+τ2)C2=(1+r1)B1+TT2Q2+L2(1+\tau_{2})C_{2}=(1+r_{1})B_{1}+TT_{2}Q_{2}+L_{2}(1+τ2​)C2​=(1+r1​)B1​+TT2​Q2​+L2​

HH's intertemporal budget constraint:

(1+τ1)C1+(1+τ2)C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+TT1Q1+L1+TT2Q2+L21+r1(1+\tau_{1})C_{1}+\frac{(1+\tau_{2})C_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+TT_{1}Q_{1}+L_{1}+\frac{TT_{2}Q_{2}+L_{2}}{1+r_{1}}(1+τ1​)C1​+1+r1​(1+τ2​)C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+TT1​Q1​+L1​+1+r1​TT2​Q2​+L2​​

Slope: [−1+τ11+τ2(1+r1)][-\frac{1+\tau_{1}}{1+\tau_{2}}(1+r_{1})][−1+τ2​1+τ1​​(1+r1​)]

The optimality condition (tangency of IC and IBC) becomes U1(C1,C2)=1+τ11+τ2(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{1+\tau_{1}}{1+\tau_{2}}(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=1+τ2​1+τ1​​(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)

  • If τ1 = τ2, then there is no change from τ1 = τ2 = 0.
  • If τ1 > τ2, then C1C_{1}C1​ becomes relatively more expensive and, assuming diminishing marginal utilities, C1C_{1}C1​ ↓ and C2C_{2}C2​ ↑.
  • If τ1 < τ2, then C1C_{1}C1​ becomes relatively cheaper and, assuming diminishing marginal utilities, C1C_{1}C1​ ↑ and C2C_{2}C2​ ↓.

Import Tariffs Equilibrium

Exogenously given are r0r_{0}r0​, B0B_{0}B0​, r∗r^{*}r∗, Q1Q_{1}Q1​, Q2Q_{2}Q2​, τ1\tau_{1}τ1​, and τ2\tau_{2}τ2​.

An equilibrium is a consumption path (C1,C2)(C_{1},C_{2})(C1​,C2​) and an interest rate r1r_{1}r1​ such that:

  • Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation
    • C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+TT1Q1+TT2Q21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}} =(1+r_{0})B_{0}+TT_{1}Q_{1}+\frac{TT_{2}Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+TT1​Q1​+1+r1​TT2​Q2​​
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U1(C1,C2)=1+τ11+τ2(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{1+\tau_{1}}{1+\tau_{2}}(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=1+τ2​1+τ1​​(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_{1}=r^{*}r1​=r∗ (free capital mobility)

Import Tariffs and TB

Question: Does an increase in import tariffs reduce imports and therefore improve TB?

TB1=TT1Q1−C1TB_{1}=TT_{1}Q_{1}-C_{1}TB1​=TT1​Q1​−C1​

An increase in import tariffs leads to

  • TB ↑ if (present import tariff > expected future import tariff)
  • TB - if (present import tariff = expected future import tariff)
  • TB ↓ if (present import tariff < expected future import tariff)

Additional observation:

  • In our model, τ1≠τ2\tau_{1}\neq\tau_{2}τ1​=τ2​ leads to lower welfare than τ1=τ2=0\tau_{1}=\tau_{2}=0τ1​=τ2​=0 (no import tariffs)
  • τ1≠τ2\tau_{1}\neq\tau_{2}τ1​=τ2​ distorts the HH's optimal intertemporal allocation

L4.2 - CA Determination in a Production Economy

Now we introduce a representative firm in the economy, and firm's decision also significantly affects TB and CA.

Rules:

  • Two-period small open economy: periods 1 and 2
  • The single consumption good is perishable
  • The single asset traded in the financial market is a bond (measured in units of the consumption good)
  • There is a representative household (HH) endowed with B0hB_{0}^{h}B0h​ units of the bond at the beginning of period 1
  • There is a representative firm. The household owns the firm and obtains the firm's profits
    • Π1\Pi_{1}Π1​ in period 1
    • Π2\Pi_{2}Π2​ in period 2
  • Interest Rates:
    • r0r_{0}r0​ for the initial bond holdings
    • r1r_{1}r1​ for the bonds held at the end of period 1

Firm

What does the firm do?

  • makes investments in period ttt that lead to output in t+1t + 1t+1
  • finances its investments in period ttt by issuing debt in ttt

Firm's Production Function

  • Q1=A1F(I0){Q}_{1}=A_{1}F(I_{0})Q1​=A1​F(I0​)
  • Q2=A2F(I1){Q}_{2}=A_{2}F(I_{1})Q2​=A2​F(I1​)
  • Notations:
    • FFF is a function
    • At>0 (t=1,2)A_{t}\gt 0\ (t=1,2)At​>0 (t=1,2) are technology parameters
    • I0I_{0}I0​ - investment in period 0 and exogeneously given
    • I1I_{1}I1​ - investment in period 1 and chosen by the firm

Firm's Debt

  • The firm issues debt Dtf(t=1,2)D_{t}^{f} (t=1,2)Dtf​(t=1,2)
  • D0f=I0D_{0}^{f}=I_{0}D0f​=I0​ (exogenous; to be repaid in period 1)
  • D1f=I1D_{1}^{f}=I_{1}D1f​=I1​ (to be repaid in period 2)

Production Function (MPK and MCK)

The firm chooses I1I_{1}I1​ by maximizing profits

Π2=A2F(I1)−(1+r1)D1f(where D1f=I1)\Pi_{2}=A_{2}F(I_{1})-(1+r_{1})D_{1}^{f} (\mathrm{where}\ D_{1}^{f}=I_{1})Π2​=A2​F(I1​)−(1+r1​)D1f​(where D1f​=I1​)

or Π2(l1)=A2F(I1)−(1+r1)I1\Pi_{2}(l_{1})=A_{2}F(I_{1})-(1+r_{1})I_{1}Π2​(l1​)=A2​F(I1​)−(1+r1​)I1​

The first-order condition for profit maximization is Π2′(I1)=0\Pi_{2}^{\prime}(I_{1})=0Π2′​(I1​)=0

Therefore, 0=A2F′(I1)−(1+r1)0=A_{2}F^{\prime}(I_{1})-(1+r_{1})0=A2​F′(I1​)−(1+r1​)

Thus, we have Optimal Investment Condition (MPK = MCK)

  • A2F′(I1)=(1+r1)A_{2}F^{\prime}(I_{1})=(1+r_{1})A2​F′(I1​)=(1+r1​)
  • Marginal Product of Capital (MPK): d[A2F(I1)]dI1=A2F′(I1){\frac{d[A_{2}F(I_{1})]}{d I_{1}}}=A_{2}F^{\prime}(I_{1})dI1​d[A2​F(I1​)]​=A2​F′(I1​)
  • Marginal Cost of Capital (MCK): (1+r1)(1+r_{1})(1+r1​)

We assume that F has the following properties:

  • F(0)=0F(0) = 0F(0)=0
  • Positive MPK: F′(l)=dF(I)dI>0F^{\prime}(l)=\frac{d F(I)}{dI}\gt 0F′(l)=dIdF(I)​>0 for all I>0I\gt 0I>0
  • Diminishing MPK: F′′(l)=dF′(I)dI<0F^{\prime\prime}(l)=\frac{d F^{\prime}(I)}{dI}\lt 0F′′(l)=dIdF′(I)​<0 for all I>0I\gt 0I>0
  • lim⁡I→0F′(I)=∞\lim_{I \to 0}F^{\prime}(I)=\inftylimI→0​F′(I)=∞ and lim⁡I→∞F′(I)=0\lim_{I \to \infty}F^{\prime}(I)=0limI→∞​F′(I)=0
  • The above properties guarantee:
    • the optimal investment condition has a unique solution
    • unique solution also maximizes profit
  • Example: F(I)=IF(I)={\sqrt{I}}F(I)=I​

Firm's Optimal Investment Decision

The firm chooses I1I_{1}I1​ so that A2F′(I1)=(1+r1)A_{2}F^{\prime}(I_{1})=(1+r_{1})A2​F′(I1​)=(1+r1​)

Household

Since the HH owns the firm, it receives the latter's profits:

  • Π1=A1F(I0)−(1+r0)D0f\Pi_{1}=A_{1}F(I_{0})-(1+r_{0})D_{0}^{f}Π1​=A1​F(I0​)−(1+r0​)D0f​
  • Π2=A2F(I1)−(1+r1)D1f\Pi_{2}=A_{2}F(I_{1})-(1+r_{1})D_{1}^{f}Π2​=A2​F(I1​)−(1+r1​)D1f​

The HH's budget constraint in period 1 is: C1+B1h=(1+r0)B0h+Π1C_{1}+B_{1}^{h}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}^{h}+\Pi_{1}C1​+B1h​=(1+r0​)B0h​+Π1​

The HH's budget constraint in period 2 is: C2+B2h=(1+r1)B1h+Π2C_{2}+B_{2}^{h}=(1+r_{1})B_{1}^{h}+\Pi_{2}C2​+B2h​=(1+r1​)B1h​+Π2​

Assume transversality condition B2h=0B_{2}^{h}=0B2h​=0

From HH's budget constraint above, we obtain the HH's intertemporal budget constraint:

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0h+Π1+Π21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}^{h}+\Pi_{1}+\frac{\Pi_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0h​+Π1​+1+r1​Π2​​

Economy's net foreign asset positions:

  • B0=B0h−D0fB_{0}=B_{0}^{h}-D_{0}^{f}B0​=B0h​−D0f​
  • B1=B1h−D1fB_{1}=B_{1}^{h}-D_{1}^{f}B1​=B1h​−D1f​
  • Notations:
    • BtB_{t}Bt​: NIIP
    • BthB_{t}^{h}Bth​: Domestic Supply
    • DtfD_{t}^{f}Dtf​: Domestic Demand

By combining all the above, we obtain the economy's intertemporal resource constraint:

Steps

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)(B0+D0f)+Π1+Π21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}=(1+r_{0})(B_{0}+D_{0}^{f})+\Pi_{1}+\frac{\Pi_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)(B0​+D0f​)+Π1​+1+r1​Π2​​

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)(B0+D0f)+[A1F(I0)−(1+r0)D0f]+A2F(I1)−(1+r1)D1f1+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}=(1+r_{0})(B_{0}+D_{0}^{f})+[A_{1}F(I_{0})-(1+r_{0})D_{0}^{f}]+\frac{A_{2}F(I_{1})-(1+r_{1})D_{1}^{f}}{1+{r_{1}}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)(B0​+D0f​)+[A1​F(I0​)−(1+r0​)D0f​]+1+r1​A2​F(I1​)−(1+r1​)D1f​​

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)(B0+D0f)+A1F(I0)−(1+r0)D0f+A2F(I1)1+r1−D1fC_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}=(1+r_{0})(B_{0}+D_{0}^{f})+A_{1}F(I_{0})-(1+r_{0})D_{0}^{f}+\frac{A_{2}F(I_{1})}{1+{r_{1}}}-D_{1}^{f}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)(B0​+D0f​)+A1​F(I0​)−(1+r0​)D0f​+1+r1​A2​F(I1​)​−D1f​

C1+C21+r1+D1f=(1+r0)(B0+D0f−D0f)+A1F(I0)+A2F(I1)1+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}+D_{1}^{f}=(1+r_{0})(B_{0}+D_{0}^{f}-D_{0}^{f})+A_{1}F(I_{0})+\frac{A_{2}F(I_{1})}{1+{r_{1}}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​+D1f​=(1+r0​)(B0​+D0f​−D0f​)+A1​F(I0​)+1+r1​A2​F(I1​)​

C1+C21+r1+D1f=(1+r0)B0+A1F(I0)+A2F(I1)1+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}+D_{1}^{f}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+A_{1}F(I_{0})+\frac{A_{2}F(I_{1})}{1+{r_{1}}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​+D1f​=(1+r0​)B0​+A1​F(I0​)+1+r1​A2​F(I1​)​

C1+C21+r1+I1=(1+r0)B0+A1F(I0)+A2F(I1)1+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}+I_{1}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+A_{1}F(I_{0})+\frac{A_{2}F(I_{1})}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​+I1​=(1+r0​)B0​+A1​F(I0​)+1+r1​A2​F(I1​)​

Equilibrium

Exogenously given are r0r_{0}r0​, B0hB_{0}^{h}B0h​, r∗r^{*}r∗, I0I_{0}I0​, D0fD_{0}^{f}D0f​, A1A_{1}A1​ and A2A_{2}A2​.

An equilibrium is (C1,C2,I1,r1)(C_{1},C_{2},I_{1},r_{1})(C1​,C2​,I1​,r1​) such that:

  • Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation
    • C1+C21+r1+I1=(1+r0)B0+A1F(I0)+A2F(I1)1+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+{r_{1}}}+I_{1}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+A_{1}F(I_{0})+\frac{A_{2}F(I_{1})}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​+I1​=(1+r0​)B0​+A1​F(I0​)+1+r1​A2​F(I1​)​
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_{1}=r^{*}r1​=r∗
  • Optimal investment condition
    • A2F′(I1)=(1+r1)A_{2}F^{\prime}(I_{1})=(1+r_{1})A2​F′(I1​)=(1+r1​)

Positive Productivity Shocks

Positive Anticipated Future Productivity Shock: Assume Δ>0\Delta\gt 0Δ>0 and that the period 2 technology parameter changes to A2′=A2+ΔA_{2}^{\prime}=A_{2}+\DeltaA2′​=A2​+Δ, while A1A_{1}A1​ remains unchanged

Firm's Decision

Productivity shocks affect the firm's optimal investment

  • Positive shock: I1I_{1}I1​ ↑, output ↑, Π2\Pi_{2}Π2​ ↑
  • Negative shock: I1I_{1}I1​ ↓, output ↓, Π2\Pi_{2}Π2​ ↓

Household's Reaction

Summary

Assuming that C1C_{1}C1​ is a normal good:

  • Δ optimal investment: A2↑→I1↑A_{2}\uparrow\to I_{1}\uparrowA2​↑→I1​↑
  • HH's reaction: A2↑→Π2↑→S1↓A_{2}\uparrow\to\Pi_{2}\uparrow\to S_{1}\downarrowA2​↑→Π2​↑→S1​↓
  • CA deteriorates: ΔCA1<0 (CA1=S1−I1)\Delta CA_{1}\lt 0\,(CA_{1}=S_{1}-I_{1})ΔCA1​<0(CA1​=S1​−I1​)

Other Productivity Shocks

Other productivity shocks includes:

  • negative anticipated future productivity shocks
  • temporary productivity shocks (A1′≠A1, A2′=A2)(A_{1}^{\prime}\neq A_{1},\,A_{2}^{\prime}=A_{2})(A1′​=A1​,A2′​=A2​)
  • permanent productivity shocks (A1′>A1, A2′>A2)(A_{1}^{\prime}\gt A_{1},\,A_{2}^{\prime}\gt A_{2})(A1′​>A1​,A2′​>A2​) or (A1′<A1, A2′<A2)(A_{1}^{\prime}\lt A_{1},\,A_{2}^{\prime}\lt A_{2})(A1′​<A1​,A2′​<A2​)

The HH's reaction to such a shock depends on:

  • shock is positive or negative
  • shock is temporary or permanent
  • shock is anticipated or not

L5.1 - Int. R. Shocks in a Production Economy

Firm's Reaction

A positive world interest rate shock:

  • decreases the firm's investment level
  • decreases output

Household's Reaction

If r∗{r}^{\ast}r∗ ↑ then HH's savings (=Π2−C1=\Pi_{2}-C_{1}=Π2​−C1​) increase

  • Substitution effect (SE)
    • Saving in period 1 becomes more attractive
  • Income effect (IE)
    • r∗{r}^{\ast}r∗ ↑ makes debtors poorer and creditors richer
  • Additional income effect (IE2)
    • Π2\Pi_{2}Π2​ (= area between MPK & MCK curves) decreases
  • Assume B0h=0B_{0}^{h}=0B0h​=0 and that C1C_{1}C1​ and C2C_{2}C2​ are normal goods

Overall, if the interest rate increases:

  • SE < 0
  • IE2 < 0 (as C1C_{1}C1​ is normal)
  • If the country is a debtor (Π1<C1A\Pi_{1}\lt C_{1}^{A}Π1​<C1A​):
    • IE < 0 as budget line shift that determines IE is to the left
    • TE = SE + IE + IE2 < 0
  • If the country is a creditor (Π1>C1A\Pi_{1}\gt C_{1}^{A}Π1​>C1A​):
    • IE > 0 as budget line shift that determines IE is to the right
    • TE > or < 0 depending on which of SE + IE2 and IE dominates
    • Economists usually consider that TE < 0

Adjustment to a World Interest Shock

Collateral Constraints and Financial Shocks

So far, we assumed that the firm can borrow freely in period 1.

In reality, firms cannot borrow freely (financial frictions)

  • e.g. Firms may not be able to commit to repay

We assume that the firm can borrow up to a collateral constraint (D1f≤κD_{1}^{f}\leq\kappaD1f​≤κ)

  • This constraint may or may not bind

firm's new optimal investment in period 1:

  • constraint binds: I1=κI_{1}=\kappaI1​=κ
  • constraint doesn't bind: I1ncI_{1}^{nc}I1nc​ such that A2F′(I1nc)=(1+r1)A_{2}F^{\prime}(I_{1}^{nc})=(1+r_{1})A2​F′(I1nc​)=(1+r1​)
  • Therefore: I1=min{κ,I1nc}I_{1}=min\{\kappa,I_{1}^{nc}\}I1​=min{κ,I1nc​}

Shocks to κ\kappaκ (financial shocks) yield interesting dynamics

L5.2 - Fiscal Deficits and CA Imbalances

Ricardian Equivalence: If government expenditures don't change, changes in the tax schedule and bond issuance don't affect the HH's consumption

Rules:

  • Two-period small open economy: periods 1 and 2
  • The single consumption good is perishable
  • Traded in the financial market are private and government bonds (both measured in units of the consumption good)
  • There is a representative household (HH) in the economy endowed with
    • B0hB_{0}^{h}B0h​ units of the bond at the beginning of period 1
    • Q1Q_{1}Q1​ units of the good in period 1
    • Q2Q_{2}Q2​ units of the good in period 2
  • There is a government
    • government has expenditures
    • government finances them by:
      • taxes
      • issuing debt
    • Government expenditures (exogeneous)
      • G1G_{1}G1​ in period 1
      • G2G_{2}G2​ in period 2
    • Taxes are levied as lump-sum taxes
      • T1T_{1}T1​ in period 1
      • T2T_{2}T2​ in period 2
    • Government assets (or debts if negative):
      • B0gB_{0}^{g}B0g​: exogeneously given at beginning of Period 1
      • B1gB_{1}^{g}B1g​: amount of government assets at the end of period 1
      • Btg<0B_{t}^{g}\lt 0Btg​<0: public debt outstanding
  • Interest Rates:
    • r0r_{0}r0​ for the initial bond holdings
    • r1r_{1}r1​ for bonds held at the end of period 1

Government's Budget Constraint

The government's budget constraints are:

  • G1+B1g=(1+r0)B0g+T1G_{1}+B_{1}^{g}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}^{g}+T_{1}G1​+B1g​=(1+r0​)B0g​+T1​
  • G2+B2g=(1+r1)B1g+T2G_{2}+B_{2}^{g}=(1+r_{1})B_{1}^{g}+T_{2}G2​+B2g​=(1+r1​)B1g​+T2​
  • Where G = Expenditure; T = Tax Revenue

Assume transversality condition: B2g=0B_{2}^{g}=0B2g​=0

Intertemporal government budget constraint

G1+G21+r1=(1+r0)B0g+T1+T21+r1G_{1}+\frac{G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+{r}_{0})B_{0}^{g}+T_{1}+\frac{T_{2}}{1+{r}_{1}}G1​+1+r1​G2​​=(1+r0​)B0g​+T1​+1+r1​T2​​

Household's Budget Constraint

The household's budget constraints are:

  • C1+T1+B1h=(1+r0)B0h+Q1C_{1}+T_{1}+B_{1}^{h}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}^{h}+Q_{1}C1​+T1​+B1h​=(1+r0​)B0h​+Q1​
  • C2+T2+B2h=(1+r1)B1h+Q2C_{2}+T_{2}+B_{2}^{h}=(1+r_{1})B_{1}^{h}+Q_{2}C2​+T2​+B2h​=(1+r1​)B1h​+Q2​

Assume transversality condition: B2h=0B_{2}^{h}=0B2h​=0

HH's intertemporal budget constraint

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0h+Q1−T1+Q2−T21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}^{h}+Q_{1}-T_{1}+\frac{Q_{2}-T_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0h​+Q1​−T1​+1+r1​Q2​−T2​​

Intertemporal Resource Constraint

NIIP Position: B0=B0h+B0gB_{0}=B_{0}^{h}+B_{0}^{g}B0​=B0h​+B0g​ (at beginning of Period 1)

  • B0B_{0}B0​: Country's NIIP
  • B0hB_{0}^{h}B0h​: Private Net Assets
  • B0gB_{0}^{g}B0g​: Government Net Assets

Combine Gov and HH's Budget Constraint:

Steps

C1+G1+C2+G21+r1=(1+r0)(B0g+B0h)+Q1+(T1−T1)+Q2+(T2−T2)1+r1C_{1}+G_{1}+\frac{C_{2}+G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+r_{0})(B_{0}^{g}+B_{0}^{h})+Q_{1}+(T_{1}-T_{1})+\frac{Q_{2}+(T_{2}-T_{2})}{1+r_{1}}C1​+G1​+1+r1​C2​+G2​​=(1+r0​)(B0g​+B0h​)+Q1​+(T1​−T1​)+1+r1​Q2​+(T2​−T2​)​

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1+Q21+r1−G1−G21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}+\frac{Q_{2}}{1+r_{1}}-G_{1}-\frac{G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​+1+r1​Q2​​−G1​−1+r1​G2​​

C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1−G1+Q2−G21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}-G_{1}+\frac{Q_{2}-G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​−G1​+1+r1​Q2​−G2​​

Equilibrium

  • Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation
    • C1+C21+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1−G1+Q2−G21+r1C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{1+r_{1}}=(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}-G_{1}+\frac{Q_{2}-G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}C1​+1+r1​C2​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​−G1​+1+r1​Q2​−G2​​
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​)
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_{1}=r^{*}r1​=r∗

Logarithmic Utility Solution

U(C1,C2)=ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2U(C_{1},C_{2})=\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2}U(C1​,C2​)=lnC1​+lnC2​

Steps

Note: Same with Lecture 3 Logarithmic Solution

Using derivatibe formula dln⁡(x)dx=1x\frac{d\ln(x)}{dx}=\frac{1}{x}dxdln(x)​=x1​, we get:

U1(C1,C2)=∂U(C1,C2)∂C1=∂(ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2)∂C1=1C1U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{\partial U(C_{1},C_{2})}{\partial C_{1}}=\frac{\partial(\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2})}{\partial C_{1}}=\frac{1}{C_{1}}U1​(C1​,C2​)=∂C1​∂U(C1​,C2​)​=∂C1​∂(lnC1​+lnC2​)​=C1​1​

U2(C1,C2)=∂U(C1,C2)∂C2=∂(ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2)∂C2=1C2U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})=\frac{\partial U(C_{1},C_{2})}{\partial C_{2}}=\frac{\partial(\ln C_{1}+\ln C_{2})}{\partial C_{2}}=\frac{1}{C_{2}}U2​(C1​,C2​)=∂C2​∂U(C1​,C2​)​=∂C2​∂(lnC1​+lnC2​)​=C2​1​

Therefore, the equilibrium condition U1(C1,C2)=(1+r1)U2(C1,C2)U_{1}(C_{1},C_{2})=(1+r_{1})U_{2}(C_{1},C_{2})U1​(C1​,C2​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1​,C2​) becomes 1C1=(1+r1)1C2{\frac{1}{C_{1}}}=(1+r_{1}){\frac{1}{C_{2}}}C1​1​=(1+r1​)C2​1​

From the above, we can derive C2=(1+r1)C1C_{2}=(1+r_{1})C_{1}C2​=(1+r1​)C1​

By substituting into Feasibility of the intertemporal allocation, we get:

C1=12[(1+r0)B0+Q1−G1+Q2−G21+r1]C_{1}={\frac{1}{2}}[(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}-G_{1}+{\frac{Q_{2}-G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}}]C1​=21​[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​−G1​+1+r1​Q2​−G2​​]

C2=12(1+r1)[(1+r0)B0+Q1−G1+Q2−G21+r1]C_{2}={\frac{1}{2}(1+r_{1})}[(1+r_{0})B_{0}+Q_{1}-G_{1}+{\frac{Q_{2}-G_{2}}{1+r_{1}}}]C2​=21​(1+r1​)[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1​−G1​+1+r1​Q2​−G2​​]

Note that:

  • government expenditures show up
  • taxes do not show up

From the above C1C_{1}C1​ and C2C_{2}C2​ (optimal consumption path):

  • Changes in G1G_{1}G1​ and G2G_{2}G2​ affect the HH's consumption
  • The following changes don't affect the consumption (as long as they satisfy intertemporal government budget constraint)
    • T1T_{1}T1​ and T2T_{2}T2​ (tax schedule)
    • B1gB_{1}^{g}B1g​ (government's asset/debt position)

Ricardian Equivalence

Ricardian Equivalence: Even if the government decreases T1T_{1}T1​ and B1gB_{1}^{g}B1g​, and instead increases T2T_{2}T2​ such that intertemporal government budget constraint remains satisfied, this won't affect the optimal consumption path

The Ricardian equivalence holds because the HH reacts to tax changes by adjusting its savings.

Consider a change ΔT1\Delta T_{1}ΔT1​ in the period 1 tax T1T_{1}T1​

Private Saving: S1p=Q1+r0B0h−T1−C1S_{1}^{p}={Q}_{1}+r_{0}B_{0}^{h}-T_{1}-C_{1}S1p​=Q1​+r0​B0h​−T1​−C1​

  • Disposable Income: Q1+r0B0h−T1{Q}_{1}+r_{0}B_{0}^{h}-T_{1}Q1​+r0​B0h​−T1​
  • Consumption: C1C_{1}C1​

Since other variables in private saving don't change, we have: ΔS1p=−ΔT1\Delta S_{1}^{p}=-\Delta T_{1}ΔS1p​=−ΔT1​

Government saving: S1g=r0B0g+T1−G1S_{1}^{g}=r_{0}B_{0}^{g}+T_{1}-G_{1}S1g​=r0​B0g​+T1​−G1​

  • Revenues: r0B0g+T1r_{0}B_{0}^{g}+T_{1}r0​B0g​+T1​
  • Expenditure: G1G_{1}G1​

Since other variables in government saving don't change, we have: ΔS1g=ΔT1\Delta S_{1}^{g}=\Delta T_{1}ΔS1g​=ΔT1​

National Saving S1=S1p+S1gS_{1}=S_{1}^{p}+S_{1}^{g}S1​=S1p​+S1g​ doesn't change:

  • ΔS1=ΔS1p+ΔS1g=−ΔT1+ΔT1=0\Delta S_{1}=\Delta S_{1}^{p}+\Delta S_{1}^{g}=-\Delta T_{1}+\Delta T_{1}=0ΔS1​=ΔS1p​+ΔS1g​=−ΔT1​+ΔT1​=0

Current Account also doesn't change:

  • ΔCA=ΔS1−ΔI1=0\Delta CA=\Delta S_{1}-\Delta I_{1}=0ΔCA=ΔS1​−ΔI1​=0
  • ΔI1=0\Delta I_{1}=0ΔI1​=0 because we did not model production
  • SUW Ch. 8: model with production in which still ΔI1=0\Delta I_{1}=0ΔI1​=0

Conclusion:

  • The Ricardian equivalence holds because changes in private and government saving exactly offsets each other
  • When the government changes the timing of taxes, rational households adjust their savings so that their consumption paths remain unaffected
  • As a result, the CA balance also does not change

Twin Deficits in the U.S

Twin Deficits: both fiscal and current account deficits

Ronald Reagan (U.S. President, 1981 - 1989)

  • Implemented tax cuts
  • Increased military spending

As a result, the fiscal deficit increased by roughly 3% of GDP

The Ricardian equivalence says:

  • Changes in taxes (T1,T2)(T_{1},T_{2})(T1​,T2​) do not affect the CA
  • Changes in (G1,G2)(G_{1},G_{2})(G1​,G2​) can affect the CA balance
    • However, the government spending increased only by 1.5% of GNP

If the Ricardian equivalence fails, a change in tax schedule can affect consumption choices.

Intergenerational effects: Those who benefit from the tax cut (today's generations) may not be the ones that pay for the future tax increase (future generations)

  • to obtain quantitatively plausible effect, all HHs have to die after one period

Distortionary taxes: changes in tax rates will tend to distort consumption, savings, and investment decisions

  • We have assumed taxes are lump-sum taxes
  • In reality, taxes are specified as a fraction of consumption, income, firm's profits, etc.

Therefore, the explanation likely has to rely on a combination of:

  • an increase in governement expenditures
  • factors that break the Ricardian equivalence:
    • Borrowing constraints
    • Intergenerational effects
    • Distortionary taxes

L6 - Uncertainty and the CA

The Great Moderation in the U.S.

The Great Moderation: The volatility of the growth rate of real U.S. GDP per capita declined significantly after (about) 1984.

Three proposed explanations:

  • Good-luck hypothesis: by chance, the U.S. economy has been blessed with smaller shocks.
  • Good-policy hypothesis: volatility declined due to
    • good monetary policy (aggressive low inflation policy of Volcker and Greenspan Feds)
    • the phasing out of Regulation Q's interest rate ceilings for most types of bank deposits (such ceilings may cause negative real interest rates on deposits if inflation is high, causing bank deposits withdrawals, consequently reduced bank loans, and finally a credit-crunch-induced recession)
  • Structural change hypothesis: the amplitude of business cycles was reduced by structural change, particularly in inventory management and in the financial sector

U.S. CA-to-GDP Ratio, 1947Q1 - 2017Q4

  • 1947-1983: on average, CA surplus of 0.34% of GDP
  • 1984-2017: on average, CA deficit of 2.8% of GDP

Open Economy Model with Uncertainty

Implication for CA

  • High uncertainty about the future (σ\sigmaσ large)
    • People save more; The CA improves
  • Low uncertainty about the future (σ\sigmaσ small; Great Moderation)
    • People save less; The CA deteriorates

Rules:

  • Two-period small open economy: periods 1 and 2
  • The single consumption good is perishable
  • The single asset traded in the financial market is a bond (measured in units of the consumption good)
  • There is a representative household (HH) endowed with
    • B0B_{0}B0​ = 0 units of the bond at the beginning of period 1
    • units of the good
      • period 1: Q1=QQ_{1}=QQ1​=Q units of the goods
      • period 2:
        • Good state (50%): Q2=Q+σQ_{2}=Q+\sigmaQ2​=Q+σ
        • Bad state (50%): Q2=Q−σQ_{2}=Q-\sigmaQ2​=Q−σ
        • Assume σ≥0\sigma\geq 0σ≥0
        • If σ>0\sigma\gt 0σ>0 then period 2 is uncertain
  • Interest Rates:
    • r0r_{0}r0​ for the initial bond holdings,
    • r1=0r_{1}=0r1​=0 for the bonds held at the end of period 1

Expected Utility Assumption

The HH cares about expected utility from consumption: U(C1,C2(⋅))=ln⁡C1+E [ln⁡C2]U(C_{1},C_{2}(\cdot))=\ln C_{1}+E\,[\ln C_{2}]U(C1​,C2​(⋅))=lnC1​+E[lnC2​]

With good state (G) and a bad state (B): U(C1,C2(⋅))=ln⁡C1+[πGln⁡C2(G)+πBln⁡C2(B)]U(C_{1},C_{2}(\cdot))=\ln C_{1}+[\pi_{G}\ln C_{2}(G)+\pi_{B}\ln C_{2}(B)]U(C1​,C2​(⋅))=lnC1​+[πG​lnC2​(G)+πB​lnC2​(B)]

  • πG\pi_{G}πG​: probability of the good state
  • πB\pi_{B}πB​: probability of the bad state
  • C2(G)C_{2}(G)C2​(G): consumption in the good state
  • C2(B)C_{2}(B)C2​(B): consumption in the bad state

Since we assume πG=πB=12\pi_{G}=\pi_{B}=\frac{1}{2}πG​=πB​=21​, we have:

U(C1,C2(⋅))=ln⁡C1+[12ln⁡C2(G)+12ln⁡C2(B)]U(C_{1},C_{2}(\cdot))=\ln C_{1}+[\frac{1}{2}\ln C_{2}(G)+\frac{1}{2}\ln C_{2}(B)]U(C1​,C2​(⋅))=lnC1​+[21​lnC2​(G)+21​lnC2​(B)]

Household's Budget Constraint

The HH's budget constraints are:

  • C1+B1=(1+r0)⋅0+QC_{1}+B_{1}=(1+r_{0})\cdot0+QC1​+B1​=(1+r0​)⋅0+Q (B1=Q−C1B_{1}=Q-C_{1}B1​=Q−C1​)
  • C2(G)=(1+0)⋅B1+Q+σC_{2}(G)=(1+0)\cdot B_{1}+Q+\sigmaC2​(G)=(1+0)⋅B1​+Q+σ (C2(G)=2Q+σ−C1C_{2}(G)=2Q+\sigma-C_{1}C2​(G)=2Q+σ−C1​)
  • C2(B)=(1+0)⋅B1+Q−σC_{2}(B)=(1+0)\cdot B_{1}+Q-\sigmaC2​(B)=(1+0)⋅B1​+Q−σ (C2(B)=2Q−σ−C1C_{2}(B)=2Q-\sigma-C_{1}C2​(B)=2Q−σ−C1​)

The household's utility maximization problem is:

max⁡C1,C2(G),C2(B)(ln⁡ C1+[12ln⁡ C2(G)+12ln⁡ C2(B)])\max_{C_{1},C_{2}(G),C_{2}(B)}(\ln\,C_{1}+[{\frac{1}{2}}\ln\,C_{2}(G)+{\frac{1}{2}}\ln\,C_{2}(B)])maxC1​,C2​(G),C2​(B)​(lnC1​+[21​lnC2​(G)+21​lnC2​(B)])

Substituting C2(G)C_{2}(G)C2​(G) and C2(B)C_{2}(B)C2​(B), we obtain:

max⁡C1(ln⁡C1+[12ln⁡(2Q+σ−C1)+12ln⁡(2Q−σ−C1)])\max_{C_{1}}(\ln C_{1}+[{\frac{1}{2}}\ln(2Q+\sigma-C_{1})+{\frac{1}{2}}\ln(2Q-\sigma-C_{1})])maxC1​​(lnC1​+[21​ln(2Q+σ−C1​)+21​ln(2Q−σ−C1​)])

Therefore, the household picks C1C_{1}C1​ to maximize her expected utility.

Maximization Condition: If f′(x∗)=0f^{\prime}(x^{*})=0f′(x∗)=0 and f′′(x)<0f^{\prime\prime}(x)\lt 0f′′(x)<0 (strictly concave), then x∗x^{*}x∗ is a global maximum of fff

Let f(C1)=(ln⁡C1+[12ln⁡(2Q+σ−C1)+12ln⁡(2Q−σ−C1)])f(C_{1})=(\ln C_{1}+[{\frac{1}{2}}\ln(2Q+\sigma-C_{1})+{\frac{1}{2}}\ln(2Q-\sigma-C_{1})])f(C1​)=(lnC1​+[21​ln(2Q+σ−C1​)+21​ln(2Q−σ−C1​)])

2nd_derivative

Note: Use Chain Rule

f′(C1)=1C1+12⋅(−1)2Q+σ−C1+12⋅(−1)2Q−σ−C1f^{\prime}(C_{1})=\frac{1}{C_{1}}+\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{(-1)}{2Q+\sigma-C_{1}}+\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{(-1)}{2Q-\sigma-C_{1}}f′(C1​)=C1​1​+21​⋅2Q+σ−C1​(−1)​+21​⋅2Q−σ−C1​(−1)​

f′(C1)=(C1)−1−12⋅(2Q+σ−C1)−1−12⋅(2Q−σ−C1)−1f^{\prime}(C_{1})=(C_{1})^{-1}-\frac{1}{2}\cdot(2Q+\sigma-C_{1})^{-1}-\frac{1}{2}\cdot(2Q-\sigma-C_{1})^{-1}f′(C1​)=(C1​)−1−21​⋅(2Q+σ−C1​)−1−21​⋅(2Q−σ−C1​)−1

f′′(C1)=(−1)(C1)−2−12(−1)(2Q+σ−C1)−2(−1)−12(−1)(2Q−σ−C1)−2(−1)f^{\prime\prime}(C_{1})=(-1)(C_{1})^{-2}-\frac{1}{2}(-1)(2Q+\sigma-C_{1})^{-2}(-1)-\frac{1}{2}(-1)(2Q-\sigma-C_{1})^{-2}(-1)f′′(C1​)=(−1)(C1​)−2−21​(−1)(2Q+σ−C1​)−2(−1)−21​(−1)(2Q−σ−C1​)−2(−1)

f′′(C1)=−(C1)−2−12(2Q+σ−C1)−2−12(2Q−σ−C1)−2f^{\prime\prime}(C_{1})=-(C_{1})^{-2}-\frac{1}{2}(2Q+\sigma-C_{1})^{-2}-\frac{1}{2}(2Q-\sigma-C_{1})^{-2}f′′(C1​)=−(C1​)−2−21​(2Q+σ−C1​)−2−21​(2Q−σ−C1​)−2

We can clearly see that all terms are negative

f′′(C1)<0f^{\prime\prime}(C_{1})\lt 0f′′(C1​)<0 (f′(C1)=0f^{\prime}(C_{1})=0f′(C1​)=0 maximizes the HH's expected utility)

Let f′(C1)=0f^{\prime}(C_{1})=0f′(C1​)=0, we have:

1C1−12[12Q+σ−C1+12Q−σ−C1]=0\frac{1}{C_{1}}-\frac{1}{2}[\frac{1}{2Q+\sigma-C_{1}}+\frac{1}{2Q-\sigma-C_{1}}]=0C1​1​−21​[2Q+σ−C1​1​+2Q−σ−C1​1​]=0

Or 1C1=12[12Q+σ−C1+12Q−σ−C1]\frac{1}{C_{1}}=\frac{1}{2}[\frac{1}{2Q+\sigma-C_{1}}+\frac{1}{2Q-\sigma-C_{1}}]C1​1​=21​[2Q+σ−C1​1​+2Q−σ−C1​1​]

Case w/o Uncertainty

Without Uncertainty: σ=0\sigma=0σ=0

1C1=12[12Q−C1+12Q−C1]\frac{1}{C_{1}}=\frac{1}{2}[\frac{1}{2Q-C_{1}}+\frac{1}{2Q-C_{1}}]C1​1​=21​[2Q−C1​1​+2Q−C1​1​]

steps

1C1=12Q−C1\frac{1}{C_{1}}=\frac{1}{2Q-C_{1}}C1​1​=2Q−C1​1​

C1=2Q−C1C_{1}=2Q-C_{1}C1​=2Q−C1​

Thus C1=QC_{1}=QC1​=Q

Therefore consumption in periods 1 and 2 is the same

  • C2(G)=C2(B)=2Q−C1=QC_{2}(G)=C_{2}(B)=2Q-C_{1}=QC2​(G)=C2​(B)=2Q−C1​=Q
  • TB1=Q−C1=0TB_{1}=Q-C_{1}=0TB1​=Q−C1​=0
  • CA1=r0B0+TB1=TB1=0CA_{1}=r_{0}B_{0}+TB_{1}=TB_{1}=0CA1​=r0​B0​+TB1​=TB1​=0
  • the HH does not need to save or borrow because the endowment stream is already perfectly smooth

Case with Uncertainty

From 1C1=12[12Q+σ−C1+12Q−σ−C1]\frac{1}{C_{1}}=\frac{1}{2}[\frac{1}{2Q+\sigma-C_{1}}+\frac{1}{2Q-\sigma-C_{1}}]C1​1​=21​[2Q+σ−C1​1​+2Q−σ−C1​1​]

steps

1C1=12[4Q−2C1(2Q−C1)2−σ2]\frac{1}{C_{1}}=\frac{1}{2}[\frac{4Q-2C_{1}}{(2Q-C_{1})^{2}-\sigma^{2}}]C1​1​=21​[(2Q−C1​)2−σ24Q−2C1​​]

4Q2−4QC1+C12−σ2=C1(2Q−C1)4Q^{2}-4QC_{1}+C_{1}^{2}-\sigma^{2}=C_{1}(2Q-C_{1})4Q2−4QC1​+C12​−σ2=C1​(2Q−C1​)

2C12−6QC1+4Q2−σ2=02C_{1}^{2}-6QC_{1}+4Q^{2}-\sigma^{2}=02C12​−6QC1​+4Q2−σ2=0

C1=6Q±36Q2−8(4Q2−σ2)4C_{1}=\frac{6Q\pm\sqrt{36Q^{2}-8(4Q^{2}-\sigma^{2})}}{4}C1​=46Q±36Q2−8(4Q2−σ2)​​

We can obtain C1=3Q±Q2+2σ22C_{1}={\frac{3Q\pm{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}}{2}}C1​=23Q±Q2+2σ2​​

However, C1=3Q+Q2+2σ22C_{1}={\frac{3Q+{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}}{2}}C1​=23Q+Q2+2σ2​​ is not feasible

  • 3Q+Q2+2σ22>3Q+Q22=2Q\frac{3Q+\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}{2}\gt \frac{3Q+\sqrt{Q^{2}}}{2}=2Q23Q+Q2+2σ2​​>23Q+Q2​​=2Q
  • Recall that:
    • C2(G)=2Q+σ−C1C_{2}(G)=2Q+\sigma-C_{1}C2​(G)=2Q+σ−C1​
    • C2(B)=2Q−σ−C1C_{2}(B)=2Q-\sigma-C_{1}C2​(B)=2Q−σ−C1​
  • If C2>0C_{2}>0C2​>0, then C1≤2Q−σC_{1}\leq2Q-\sigmaC1​≤2Q−σ

Therefore, the only solution is C1=3Q−Q2+2σ22C_{1}=\frac{3Q-{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}}{2}C1​=23Q−Q2+2σ2​​

Finally we have:

  • C2(G)=2Q+σ−3Q−Q2+2σ22C_{2}(G)=2Q+\sigma-\frac{3Q-{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}}{2}C2​(G)=2Q+σ−23Q−Q2+2σ2​​
  • C2(B)=2Q−σ−3Q−Q2+2σ22C_{2}(B)=2Q-\sigma-\frac{3Q-{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}}{2}C2​(B)=2Q−σ−23Q−Q2+2σ2​​

Analysis

C1=3Q−Q2+2σ22=Q−Q2+2σ2−Q2C_{1}={\frac{3Q-{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}}}{2}}=Q-\frac{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}-Q}{2}C1​=23Q−Q2+2σ2​​=Q−2Q2+2σ2​−Q​

  • precautionary saving: Q2+2σ2−Q2\frac{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}-Q}{2}2Q2+2σ2​−Q​
  • If σ=0\sigma =0σ=0, then precautionary savings are zero.
  • σ\sigmaσ ↑ >> precautionary saving ↑ >> C1C_{1}C1​ ↓

C2(B)=Q−σ+Q2+2σ2−Q2C_{2}(B)=Q-\sigma +\frac{\sqrt{Q^{2}+2\sigma^{2}}-Q}{2}C2​(B)=Q−σ+2Q2+2σ2​−Q​

  • Q2=Q−σQ_{2}=Q-\sigmaQ2​=Q−σ
  • When σ\sigmaσ increases, Q2Q_{2}Q2​ decreases in the bad state
  • The household tries to avoid low consumption in the bad state by increasing her precautionary saving
  • This has an implication for the CA as well

Implication for CA

TB1=Q−C1(σ)TB_{1}=Q-C_{1}(\sigma)TB1​=Q−C1​(σ)

Since CA1=r0B0+TB1CA_{1}=r_{0}B_{0}+TB_{1}CA1​=r0​B0​+TB1​ and B0=0B_{0}=0B0​=0 (assumption):

  • CA=TB1=Q−C1(σ)CA=TB_{1}=Q-C_{1}(\sigma)CA=TB1​=Q−C1​(σ)
  • In response to an increase in uncertainty σ\sigmaσ, the HH uses the trade balance as a vehicle to save in period 1

Therefore the conclusion:

  • High uncertainty: People save more; The CA improves
  • Low uncertainty: People save less; The CA deteriorates

L7 - External Adjustment in Open Economies

Current Account Schedule

The current account balance is an increasing function of r1r_{1}r1​

Interest Rate Shock

  • A positive shock to the interest rate (r∗r^{*}r∗ → r∗′r^{*\prime}r∗′)
  • CA1CA_{1}CA1​ improves if there is a positive interest rate shock

Temporary Productivity Shock

Following a positive shock to the period-1 efficiency parameter (A1A_{1}A1​ → A1′A_{1}^{\prime}A1′​), CA1CA_{1}CA1​ improves

Anticipated Future Productivity Shock

A positive shock to the period-2 efficiency parameter (A2A_{2}A2​ → A2′A_{2}^{\prime}A2′​), CA1CA_{1}CA1​ deteriorates

Country Risk Premium

  • Emerging countries often face a higher interest rate
  • when country is debtor, the world interest rate is raised by a country risk premium (p)
    • If CA1≥0CA_{1}\geq0CA1​≥0, no risk premium
    • If CA1<0CA_{1}\lt0CA1​<0, risk premium p
  • accumulates more debt -> higher interest rate

Positive anticipated future productivity shock: If CA1<0CA_{1}\lt0CA1​<0, then an investment surge leads to a smaller CA deterioration than with a constant risk premium

Large Open Economy

Two-country model:

  • the U.S.
  • the rest of the world (RW)

CAUS=−CARWCA^{US}=-CA^{RW}CAUS=−CARW

Important: Now, the U.S. CA balance affects the world interest rate.

Investment Surge in a Large Open Economy

  • Following the positive anticipated future productivity shock in the U.S. economy:
    • The U.S. CA schedule shifts left from CAUSCA^{US}CAUS to CAUS′CA^{US\prime}CAUS′
    • The equilibrium point moves from A to A′A^{\prime}A′
  • The resulting change in the U.S.:
    • CA is smaller
    • domestic interest rate is larger than the one in a small open economy setup
    • In a small open economy, the eqm. moves from A to D
  • The resulting change in the U.S.:
    • CA is larger
    • domestic interest rate is smaller than the one in a closed economy setup
    • In a closed economy CA=0CA = 0CA=0 and the equilibrium moves from B to B′B^{\prime}B′

The U.S. Current Account Deficit

CA deficit: during 1996-2006 ballooned from 1.5% to 6% of GDP, then sharply improved to ≤ 3% of GDP by 2009. Is it driven by domestic or external factors?

Made in the U.S.A. hypothesis

Global Saving Glut hypothesis

Test the hypothesis

Period of 1996-2005 (global saving glut hypothesis)

  • The world interest rate fell during this period

Period of 2006-2018 (made in the U.S.A. hypothesis)

  • The CA deficit actually improved during this period
  • Under the global saving glut hypothesis, this would be attributed to a decline in saving in the rest of the world and be accompanied by an increase in the world interest rate
  • However, the world interest rate fell during 2005-2018

Large Open Economies Analysis

Key: Both countries affect the world interest rate

Setup:

  • Two periods: periods 1 and 2
  • Two countries: China (C) and the United States (US)
  • The single consumption good is perishable
  • The single asset traded in the financial markets is a bond (measured in units of the consumption good)
  • In each country x∈{C,US}x \in \{C, US\}x∈{C,US}, there is a representative household (HH) endowed with
    • B0x=0B^x_0 = 0B0x​=0 units of the bond at the beginning of period 1
    • Q1xQ^x_1Q1x​ units of the good in period 1
    • Q2xQ^x_2Q2x​ units of the good in period 2
  • Interest Rates for bonds held at the end of period 1:
    • r1r_1r1​ for the U.S
    • r1Cr^C_1r1C​ for China
    • r1∗r^*_1r1∗​ for the world

An equilibrium requires six conditions:

  • Feasibility and optimality in China
    • C1C+C2C1+r1C=Q1C+Q2C1+r1CC_1^C + \frac{C_2^C}{1+r_1^C} = Q_1^C + \frac{Q_2^C}{1+r_1^C}C1C​+1+r1C​C2C​​=Q1C​+1+r1C​Q2C​​
    • U1(C1C,C2C)=(1+r1C)U2(C1C,C2C)U_1(C_1^C, C_2^C) = (1 + r_1^C)U_2(C_1^C, C_2^C)U1​(C1C​,C2C​)=(1+r1C​)U2​(C1C​,C2C​)
  • Feasibility and optimality in the U.S.
    • C1US+C2US1+r1=Q1US+Q2US1+r1C_1^{US} + \frac{C_2^{US}}{1+r_1} = Q_1^{US} + \frac{Q_2^{US}}{1+r_1}C1US​+1+r1​C2US​​=Q1US​+1+r1​Q2US​​
    • U1(C1US,C2US)=(1+r1)U2(C1US,C2US)U_1(C_1^{US}, C_2^{US}) = (1 + r_1)U_2(C_1^{US}, C_2^{US})U1​(C1US​,C2US​)=(1+r1​)U2​(C1US​,C2US​)
  • Interest rate and current account conditions
    • r1=r1C=r1∗r_1 = r_1^C = r_1^*r1​=r1C​=r1∗​
    • CAC(r∗)+CA1US(r∗)=0CA^C(r^*) + CA_1^{US}(r^*) = 0CAC(r∗)+CA1US​(r∗)=0

Assume log utility for both countries: U(C1,C2)=ln⁡C1+ln⁡C2U(C_1, C_2) = \ln C_1 + \ln C_2U(C1​,C2​)=lnC1​+lnC2​

We have:

  • C1C=12(Q1C+Q2C1+r1C)C_1^C = \frac{1}{2} (Q_1^C + \frac{Q_2^C}{1 + r_1^C})C1C​=21​(Q1C​+1+r1C​Q2C​​)
  • C2C=12(1+r1C)(Q1C+Q2C1+r1C)C_2^C = \frac{1}{2} (1 + r_1^C)(Q_1^C + \frac{Q_2^C}{1 + r_1^C})C2C​=21​(1+r1C​)(Q1C​+1+r1C​Q2C​​)
  • C1US=12[Q1US+Q2US1+r1]C_1^{US} = \frac{1}{2}[Q_1^{US} + \frac{Q_2^{US}}{1 + r_1}]C1US​=21​[Q1US​+1+r1​Q2US​​]
  • C2US=12(1+r1)[Q1US+Q2US1+r1]C_2^{US} = \frac{1}{2} (1 + r_1)[Q_1^{US} + \frac{Q_2^{US}}{1 + r_1}]C2US​=21​(1+r1​)[Q1US​+1+r1​Q2US​​]

Assume China's endowment is growing:

  • Let QQQ denote some specific amount of the good
  • Q1C=12QQ_1^C = \frac{1}{2} QQ1C​=21​Q and Q2C=QQ_2^C = QQ2C​=Q
  • Q1US=QQ_1^{US} = QQ1US​=Q and Q2US=QQ_2^{US} = QQ2US​=Q

In this case, we can show that:

  • C1C=12[12Q+Q1+r1C]C_1^C = \frac{1}{2}[\frac{1}{2} Q + \frac{Q}{1 + r_1^C}]C1C​=21​[21​Q+1+r1C​Q​]
  • C2C=12(1+r1C)[12Q+Q1+r1C]C_2^C = \frac{1}{2} (1 + r_1^C)[\frac{1}{2} Q + \frac{Q}{1 + r_1^C}]C2C​=21​(1+r1C​)[21​Q+1+r1C​Q​]
  • C1US=12[Q+Q1+r1]C_1^{US} = \frac{1}{2}[Q + \frac{Q}{1 + r_1}]C1US​=21​[Q+1+r1​Q​]
  • C2US=12(1+r1)[Q+Q1+r1]C_2^{US} = \frac{1}{2} (1 + r_1)[Q + \frac{Q}{1 + r_1}]C2US​=21​(1+r1​)[Q+1+r1​Q​]

This implies:

  • CA1C=TB1C+rB0C=TB1C=Q1C−C1C=14Qr1C−11+r1CCA_1^C = TB_1^C + rB_0^C = TB_1^C = Q_1^C - C_1^C = \frac{1}{4}Q\frac{r_{1}^{C}-1}{1+r_{1}^{C}}CA1C​=TB1C​+rB0C​=TB1C​=Q1C​−C1C​=41​Q1+r1C​r1C​−1​ (1)
  • CA1US=TB1US+rB0US=TB1US=Q1US−C1US=12Qr11+r1CA_1^{US} = TB_1^{US} + rB_0^{US} = TB_1^{US} = Q_1^{US} - C_1^{US} = \frac{1}{2}Q\frac{r_{1}}{1+r_{1}}CA1US​=TB1US​+rB0US​=TB1US​=Q1US​−C1US​=21​Q1+r1​r1​​ (2)

Now we can solve for the world interest rate r1∗r_1^*r1∗​ using:

  • r1=r1C=r1∗r_1 = r_1^C = r_1^*r1​=r1C​=r1∗​ (3)
  • CA1C(r∗)+CA1US(r∗)=0CA_1^C(r^*) + CA_1^{US}(r^*) = 0CA1C​(r∗)+CA1US​(r∗)=0 (3)

In this example, (1)-(4) imply: r1∗=13r_1^* = \frac{1}{3}r1∗​=31​

To solve other variables:

  • Once we calculated r1∗r_1^*r1∗​, other variables are easily obtained
  • Using r1=r1C=r1∗r_1 = r_1^C = r_1^*r1​=r1C​=r1∗​, we can solve for (C1C,C2C)(C_1^C, C_2^C)(C1C​,C2C​) and (C1US,C2US)(C_1^{US}, C_2^{US})(C1US​,C2US​)
  • CA1CCA_1^CCA1C​ and CA1USCA_1^{US}CA1US​ can be calculated from (1)-(2)
  • (TB1C,TB2C)(TB_1^C, TB_2^C)(TB1C​,TB2C​), (TB1US,TB2US)(TB_1^{US}, TB_2^{US})(TB1US​,TB2US​), B1CB_1^CB1C​ and B1USB_1^{US}B1US​ can be also calculated

Capital Control in a Large Open Economy

  • In this example:
    • China is a debtor in the first period B1C=CA1C<0B_1^C = CA_1^C < 0B1C​=CA1C​<0
    • the U.S. is a creditor in the first period
  • Because China is a debtor, if it can lower the world interest rate, it would improve China's domestic welfare
  • Therefore, China has an incentive to improve its CA balance in order to drive down the world interest rate
  • The Chinese government may want to try to influence the world interest rate through capital control
    • E.g., it may try to induce the Chinese HH to consume less and save more in period 1
    • To this end, it may impose a “capital control tax” on international borrowing to increase the domestic interest rate

L8 - PPP and the Real Exchange Rate

The real exchange rate measures how expensive a foreign
country is relative to the home country. It measures the price of a basket of goods abroad in terms of baskets of good at home.

Law of One Price (LOOP)

The Law of One Price for a particular good holds if P=εP∗P = \varepsilon P^*P=εP∗.

Here:

  • PPP = good's domestic-currency price in the domestic country
  • P∗P^*P∗ = good's foreign-currency price in the foreign country
  • ε\varepsilonε = nominal exchange rate
    • ε\varepsilonε is the domestic-currency price of one unit of foreign currency
    • ε\varepsilonε (or 1ε\frac{1}{\varepsilon}ε1​) is what TV news report as an exchange rate
  • E.g.: If 1kg of apples costs 7.33USD in the U.S., ε\varepsilonε = 1.5 & LOOP holds, then 1kg of apples costs 11AUD in Australia

However, the real world is not frictionless!

  • LOOP hold well:
    • commodities: gold, oil, soy beans, wheat
    • luxury consumer goods: Rolex watches
  • LOOP not hold well:
    • personal services: health care, education, restaurant meals, haircuts
    • housing, utilities
    • transportation

Big Mac index

The idea is to compare

  • the price of a Big Mac in a foreign country: PBigMac∗P_{BigMac}^*PBigMac∗​
  • the price of a Big Mac in the U.S.: PBigMacP_{BigMac}PBigMac​
  • To compare these prices, define the Big Mac index by eBigMac=εPBigMac∗PBigMace^{BigMac} = \frac{\varepsilon P^{BigMac*}}{P^{BigMac}}eBigMac=PBigMacεPBigMac∗​
  • The LOOP for BigMacs holds if and only if eBigMac=1e^{BigMac} = 1eBigMac=1

The Big-Mac Real Exchange Rate, January 2019

Country PBigMac∗P^{BigMac*}PBigMac∗ ε\varepsilonε εPBigMac∗\varepsilon P^{BigMac*}εPBigMac∗ eBigMace^{BigMac}eBigMac eBigMacPPPe^{BigMac PPP}eBigMacPPP
Switzerland 6.50 1.02 6.62 1.19 0.86
United States 5.58 1 5.58 1 1
Canada 6.77 0.75 5.08 0.91 0.82
Euro area 4.05 1.15 4.64 0.83 1.38
China 20.90 0.15 3.05 0.55 0.27
India 178 0.01 2.55 0.46 0.03
Russia 110.17 0.01 1.65 0.30 0.05

Conclusion:

  • For the Big Mac, the Law of One Price clearly fails
  • The last column shows the PPP exchange rate for Big Macs, eBigMacPPP=PBigMacUSPBigMac∗e^{BigMac PPP} = \frac{P^{BigMacUS}}{P^{BigMac*}}eBigMacPPP=PBigMac∗PBigMacUS​

Purchasing Power Parity (PPP)

Purchasing power parity (PPP) is a generalization of the
law of one price

The real exchange rate is defined as e=εP∗Pe = \frac{\varepsilon P^*}{P}e=PεP∗​

  • PPP = domestic currency price of a (representative) domestic basket of goods
  • P∗P^*P∗ = foreign price of a (representative) foreign basket of goods
  • ε\varepsilonε = nominal exchange rate

We say (absolute) PPP holds when e=1e = 1e=1 or P=εP∗P = \varepsilon P^*P=εP∗.

Relative PPP

We say that relative PPP holds when Δe=0\Delta e = 0Δe=0.

  • PPP = domestic consumer price index
  • P∗P^*P∗ = foreign consumer price index
  • e=εP∗Pe = \frac{\varepsilon P^*}{P}e=PεP∗​

Relative PPP can be tested with CPI data

To understand what relative PPP implies, consider:

  • εt+1=εt+1Pt+1∗Pt+1\varepsilon_{t+1} = \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1} P^*_{t+1}}{P_{t+1}}εt+1​=Pt+1​εt+1​Pt+1∗​​
  • εt=εtPt∗Pt\varepsilon_t = \frac{\varepsilon_t P^*_t}{P_t}εt​=Pt​εt​Pt∗​​

Let Δx≡xt+1xt−1\Delta x \equiv \frac{x_{t+1}}{x_t} - 1Δx≡xt​xt+1​​−1. Then, by dividing et+1e_{t+1}et+1​ by ete_tet​, we get: (1+Δe)=(1+Δε)(1+ΔP∗)(1+ΔP)(1 + \Delta e) = \frac{(1 + \Delta \varepsilon)(1 + \Delta P^*)}{(1 + \Delta P)}(1+Δe)=(1+ΔP)(1+Δε)(1+ΔP∗)​

Taking logarithms on both sides and recalling that ln⁡(1+x)≈x\ln(1 + x) \approx xln(1+x)≈x for xxx small, we get: Δe≈Δε+ΔP∗−ΔP\Delta e \approx \Delta \varepsilon + \Delta P^* - \Delta PΔe≈Δε+ΔP∗−ΔP

Finally, if relative PPP holds then Δe=0\Delta e = 0Δe=0 and ΔP=Δε+ΔP∗\Delta P = \Delta \varepsilon + \Delta P^*ΔP=Δε+ΔP∗

  • Relative PPP restricts the joint evolution of PPP, P∗P^*P∗, and ε\varepsilonε
  • To test the above equation, we only need to know changes

PPP Summary

  • Absolute PPP doesn't hold in the data
  • Relative PPP holds in the long-run data
  • Relative PPP doesn't hold in the short run data

Nontradable Goods

Possible reason for the failure of PPP: nontradable goods (haircut, restaurant meals, housing, some health services, some educational services, fresh lettuce, etc)

Setup:

  • Tradable goods prices: PTP_TPT​ and PT∗P_T^*PT∗​
  • Nontradable goods prices: PNP_NPN​ and PN∗P_N^*PN∗​
  • Suppose the LOOP holds for tradable goods so that PT=εPT∗P_T = \varepsilon P_T^*PT​=εPT∗​
  • Suppose the LOOP does not hold for nontradable goods so that PN≠εPN∗P_N \neq \varepsilon P_N^*PN​=εPN∗​
  • Assume that the aggregate price level is some average of PTP_TPT​ and PNP_NPN​ as given by P=ϕ(PT,PN)P = \phi(P_T, P_N)P=ϕ(PT​,PN​)
  • The same for the foreign price level: P∗=ϕ(PT∗,PN∗)P^* = \phi(P_T^*, P_N^*)P∗=ϕ(PT∗​,PN∗​)
  • We assume the following property for the function ϕ(⋅,⋅)\phi(\cdot, \cdot)ϕ(⋅,⋅):
    • ϕ(PT,PN)\phi(P_T, P_N)ϕ(PT​,PN​) is increasing in both PTP_TPT​ and PNP_NPN​
    • For every λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0, ϕ(λPT,λPN)=λϕ(PT,PN)\phi(\lambda P_T, \lambda P_N) = \lambda \phi(P_T, P_N)ϕ(λPT​,λPN​)=λϕ(PT​,PN​)

Then, we have e=εP∗P=εϕ(PT∗,PN∗)ϕ(PT,PN)=εPT∗ϕ(1,PN∗/PT∗)PTϕ(1,PN/PT)=ϕ(1,PN∗/PT∗)ϕ(1,PN/PT)e = \frac{\varepsilon P^*}{P} = \frac{\varepsilon \phi(P_T^*, P_N^*)}{\phi(P_T, P_N)} = \frac{\varepsilon P_T^* \phi(1, P_N^* / P_T^*)}{P_T \phi(1, P_N / P_T)} = \frac{\phi(1, P_N^* / P_T^*)}{\phi(1, P_N / P_T)}e=PεP∗​=ϕ(PT​,PN​)εϕ(PT∗​,PN∗​)​=PT​ϕ(1,PN​/PT​)εPT∗​ϕ(1,PN∗​/PT∗​)​=ϕ(1,PN​/PT​)ϕ(1,PN∗​/PT∗​)​

  • last equality holds because of LOOP (PT=εPT∗P_T = \varepsilon P_T^*PT​=εPT∗​)

Observe that in general, e≠1e \neq 1e=1:

  • e≷1e \gtrless 1e≷1 if and only if PN∗PT∗≷PNPT\frac{P_N^*}{P_T^*} \gtrless \frac{P_N}{P_T}PT∗​PN∗​​≷PT​PN​​
  • With nontradable goods, absolute PPP systematically fails

Balassa-Samuelson Model

Think about two types of firms producing tradable and nontradable goods

  • Production function for tradable goods: QT=aTLTQ_T = a_T L_TQT​=aT​LT​
  • Production function for nontradable goods: QN=aNLNQ_N = a_N L_NQN​=aN​LN​
  • Profit for the firm producing tradable goods: Profit = PT(aTLT)P_T (a_T L_T)PT​(aT​LT​) - wLTw L_TwLT​
  • Profit for the firm producing nontradable goods: Profit = PN(aNLN)P_N (a_N L_N)PN​(aN​LN​) - wLNw L_NwLN​
  • We assume free labor mobility and perfect competition in both output markets

Perfect competition implies zero profit for operating firms

  • PT(aTLT)P_T (a_T L_T)PT​(aT​LT​) - wLT=0w L_T = 0wLT​=0
  • PN(aNLN)P_N (a_N L_N)PN​(aN​LN​) - wLN=0w L_N = 0wLN​=0

These two equations imply:

  • PTaT=wP_{T}a_{T}=wPT​aT​=w
  • PNaN=wP_{N}a_{N}=wPN​aN​=w

Thus, we get: PTPN=aNaT{\frac{P_{T}}{P_{N}}}={\frac{a_{N}}{a_{T}}}PN​PT​​=aT​aN​​

Similarly, we can derive: PT∗PN∗=aN∗aT∗\frac{P_{T}^{*}}{P_{N}^{*}}=\frac{a_{N}^{*}}{a_{T}^{*}}PN∗​PT∗​​=aT∗​aN∗​​

By plugging in productivities, we get: e=ϕ(1,aT∗/aN∗)ϕ(1,aT/aN)e = \frac{\phi(1, a_T^* / a_N^*)}{\phi(1, a_T / a_N)}e=ϕ(1,aT​/aN​)ϕ(1,aT∗​/aN∗​)​

If ϕ(PT,PN) = PTPN\phi(P_{T},P_{N})\,=\,\sqrt{P_{T}P_{N}}ϕ(PT​,PN​)=PT​PN​​, we have e=aT∗/aN∗aT/aNe = {\frac{\sqrt{a_{T}^{*}/a_{N}^{*}}}{\sqrt{a_{T}/a_{N}}}}e=aT​/aN​​aT∗​/aN∗​​​

The real exchange rate depends on the two countries' difference in relative productivities of tradables and nontradables

If aTaN\frac{a_T}{a_N}aN​aT​​ increases over time then eee decreases:

  • i.e., the real exchange rate appreciates (towards the domestic country)
  • The domestic country becomes relatively more expensive

Countries with higher per capita GDP tend to be more expensive

In poor countries, the productivity for tradable goods aT∗a_{T}^{*}aT∗​ is typically quite low.

For poor countries, we have: e=ϕ(1,aT∗/aN∗)ϕ(1,aTUS/aNUS)e = \frac{\phi(1, a_T^* / a_N^*)}{\phi(1, a_T^{US} / a_N^{US})}e=ϕ(1,aTUS​/aNUS​)ϕ(1,aT∗​/aN∗​)​

Trade Barriers

Trade barriers (such as import tariffs, export subsidies, quotas) can also generate deviations from PPP

Consider a country with two types of (tradable) goods:

  • Importable goods (the country imports some), with domestic price PMP_MPM​ and world price PM∗P_M^*PM∗​
  • Exportable goods (the country exports some), with domestic price PXP_XPX​ and world price PX∗P_X^*PX∗​

First, if there are no trade barriers, the LOOP must hold for both types of goods:

  • PM=εPM∗P_M = \varepsilon P_M^*PM​=εPM∗​
  • PX=εPX∗P_X = \varepsilon P_X^*PX​=εPX∗​

Then, for the real exchange rate, we get:

e=εP∗P=εϕ(PX∗,PM∗)ϕ(PX,PM)=ϕ(εPX∗,εPM∗)ϕ(PX,PM)=1e = \frac{\varepsilon P^*}{P} = \frac{\varepsilon \phi(P_X^*, P_M^*)}{\phi(P_X, P_M)} = \frac{\phi(\varepsilon P_X^*, \varepsilon P_M^*)}{\phi(P_X, P_M)} = 1e=PεP∗​=ϕ(PX​,PM​)εϕ(PX∗​,PM∗​)​=ϕ(PX​,PM​)ϕ(εPX∗​,εPM∗​)​=1

Without trade barriers, absolute PPP holds. The countries and the rest of the world are equally expensive.

Now with import tariff τ > 0, PM=(1+τ)εPM∗P_M = (1+τ)\varepsilon P_M^*PM​=(1+τ)εPM∗​, and we have:

e=εP∗P=εϕ(PX∗,PM∗)ϕ(PX,PM)=ϕ(εPX∗,εPM∗)ϕ(PX,PM)=ϕ(εPX∗,εPM∗)ϕ(εPX∗,(1+τ)εPM∗)<1e = \frac{\varepsilon P^*}{P} = \frac{\varepsilon \phi(P_X^*, P_M^*)}{\phi(P_X, P_M)} = \frac{\phi(\varepsilon P_X^*, \varepsilon P_M^*)}{\phi(P_X, P_M)} = \frac{\phi(\varepsilon P_X^*, \varepsilon P_M^*)}{\phi(\varepsilon P_X^*, (1+τ)\varepsilon P_M^*)} < 1e=PεP∗​=ϕ(PX​,PM​)εϕ(PX∗​,PM∗​)​=ϕ(PX​,PM​)ϕ(εPX∗​,εPM∗​)​=ϕ(εPX∗​,(1+τ)εPM∗​)ϕ(εPX∗​,εPM∗​)​<1

L9 - Sudden Stops and Real Exchange Rates

Sudden Stop: cutoff from international capital markets and hence capital inflows stopped abruptly

Sudden Stop Model

A sharp increase in the interest rate for borrowing, r1r_1r1​ (harder to borrow from ROW)

Setup:

  • 2 Periods
  • Representative HH
  • tradable and nontradable consumption goods
  • There is a single asset, a bond, in this world (HH holds B0B_0B0​ units at beginning)
  • Endowment: The household is endowed with:
    • Q1TQ_1^TQ1T​ units of tradables and Q1NQ_1^NQ1N​ units of nontradables in period 1
    • Q2TQ_2^TQ2T​ units of tradables and Q2NQ_2^NQ2N​ units of nontradables in period 2
  • Consumption: The household's consumption choices are
    • C1TC_1^TC1T​ for tradables and C1NC_1^NC1N​ for nontradables in period 1
    • C2TC_2^TC2T​ for tradables and C2NC_2^NC2N​ for nontradables in period 2
  • Price of goods are determined in equilibrium:
    • p1p_1p1​ = price of nontradables relative to that of tradables in period 1
    • p2p_2p2​ = price of nontradables relative to that of tradables in period 2

Real Exchange Rate

The real exchange rate in each period (t = 1, 2) is defined as et=εtPt∗Pte_t = \frac{\varepsilon_t P_t^*}{P_t}et​=Pt​εt​Pt∗​​

  • Pt≡ϕ(PtT,PtN)P_t \equiv \phi(P_t^T, P_t^N)Pt​≡ϕ(PtT​,PtN​) is the aggregate price level for the home country
  • Pt∗≡ϕ(PtT∗,PtN∗)P_t^* \equiv \phi(P_t^{T*}, P_t^{N*})Pt∗​≡ϕ(PtT∗​,PtN∗​) is the aggregate price level for the rest of the world

We assume that the function ϕ(⋅,⋅)\phi(\cdot, \cdot)ϕ(⋅,⋅) has the following properties:

  • ϕ(PtT,PtN)\phi(P_t^T, P_t^N)ϕ(PtT​,PtN​) is increasing in both PTtP_T^tPTt​ and PNtP_N^tPNt​
  • For every λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0, we have ϕ(λPTt,λPNt)=λϕ(PtT,PtN)\phi(\lambda P_T^t, \lambda P_N^t) = \lambda \phi(P_t^T, P_t^N)ϕ(λPTt​,λPNt​)=λϕ(PtT​,PtN​)

Then, we have et=εtPt∗Pt=εtϕ(PtT∗,PtN∗)ϕ(PtT,PtN)=εtPT∗tϕ(1,PtT∗/PtN∗)PTtϕ(1,PtT/PtN)=ϕ(1,PtT∗/PtN∗)ϕ(1,PtT/PtN)=ϕ(1,1)ϕ(1,pt)e_t = \frac{\varepsilon_t P_t^*}{P_t} = \frac{\varepsilon_t \phi(P_t^{T*}, P_t^{N*})}{\phi(P_t^T, P_t^N)} = \frac{\varepsilon_t P_T^{*t} \phi(1, P_t^{T*} / P_t^{N*})}{P_T^t \phi(1, P_t^T / P_t^N)} = \frac{\phi(1, P_t^{T*} / P_t^{N*})}{\phi(1, P_t^T / P_t^N)} = \frac{\phi(1, 1)}{\phi(1, p_t)}et​=Pt​εt​Pt∗​​=ϕ(PtT​,PtN​)εt​ϕ(PtT∗​,PtN∗​)​=PTt​ϕ(1,PtT​/PtN​)εt​PT∗t​ϕ(1,PtT∗​/PtN∗​)​=ϕ(1,PtT​/PtN​)ϕ(1,PtT∗​/PtN∗​)​=ϕ(1,pt​)ϕ(1,1)​

Here we assumed that the price ratio of nontradables and tradables in the ROW is constant; in particular: PtN∗PtT∗=1\frac{P_t^{N*}}{P_t^{T*}} = 1PtT∗​PtN∗​​=1 for all t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2

Note also that we have, by definition, PtNPtT=pt\frac{P_t^N}{P_t^T} = p_tPtT​PtN​​=pt​ for all t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2

Household's Budget Constraint

The budget constraint is expressed in tradable goods as the unit of measure

Therefore, we have:

  • C1T+p1C1N+B1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+p1Q1NC_1^T + p_1 C_1^N + B_1 = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + p_1 Q_1^NC1T​+p1​C1N​+B1​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+p1​Q1N​ (1)
  • C2T+p2C2N=(1+r1)B1+Q2T+p2Q2NC_2^T + p_2 C_2^N = (1 + r_1) B_1 + Q_2^T + p_2 Q_2^NC2T​+p2​C2N​=(1+r1​)B1​+Q2T​+p2​Q2N​ (2)

By combining (1) and (2), we can derive the household's intertemporal budget constraint: C1T+p1C1N+C2T+p2C2N1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+p1Q1N+Q2T+p2Q2N1+r1C_1^T + p_1 C_1^N + \frac{C_2^T + p_2 C_2^N}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + p_1 Q_1^N + \frac{Q_2^T + p_2 Q_2^N}{1 + r_1}C1T​+p1​C1N​+1+r1​C2T​+p2​C2N​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+p1​Q1N​+1+r1​Q2T​+p2​Q2N​​

Utility Function with Tradables and Nontradables

U(C1T,C1N,C2T,C2N)=lnC1T+lnC1N+lnC2T+lnC2NU(C_{1}^{T},C_{1}^{N},C_{2}^{T},C_{2}^{N})=ln C_{1}^{T}+ln C_{1}^{N}+ln C_{2}^{T}+ln C_{2}^{N}U(C1T​,C1N​,C2T​,C2N​)=lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​

We extend to the four-good case:

  • −U1U2=−1p1-\frac{U_1}{U_2} = -\frac{1}{p_1}−U2​U1​​=−p1​1​
  • −U1U3=−(1+r1)-\frac{U_1}{U_3} = -(1 + r_1)−U3​U1​​=−(1+r1​)
  • −U1U4=−1p2(1+r1)-\frac{U_1}{U_4} = -\frac{1}{p_2}(1 + r_1)−U4​U1​​=−p2​1​(1+r1​)

And we have:

  • U1=∂U(C1T,C1N,C2T,C2N)∂C1TU_1 = \frac{\partial U(C_1^T, C_1^N, C_2^T, C_2^N)}{\partial C_1^T}U1​=∂C1T​∂U(C1T​,C1N​,C2T​,C2N​)​
  • U2=∂U(C1T,C1N,C2T,C2N)∂C1NU_2 = \frac{\partial U(C_1^T, C_1^N, C_2^T, C_2^N)}{\partial C_1^N}U2​=∂C1N​∂U(C1T​,C1N​,C2T​,C2N​)​
  • U3=∂U(C1T,C1N,C2T,C2N)∂C2TU_3 = \frac{\partial U(C_1^T, C_1^N, C_2^T, C_2^N)}{\partial C_2^T}U3​=∂C2T​∂U(C1T​,C1N​,C2T​,C2N​)​
  • U4=∂U(C1T,C1N,C2T,C2N)∂C2NU_4 = \frac{\partial U(C_1^T, C_1^N, C_2^T, C_2^N)}{\partial C_2^N}U4​=∂C2N​∂U(C1T​,C1N​,C2T​,C2N​)​

Resource Constraint

Market Clearing Conditions (all the nontradables are consumed within the country):

  • C1N=Q1NC_{1}^{N}=Q_{1}^{N}C1N​=Q1N​
  • C2N=Q2NC_{2}^{N}=Q_{2}^{N}C2N​=Q2N​

Therefore, C1T+p1C1N+C2T+p2C2N1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+p1Q1N+Q2T+p2Q2N1+r1C_1^T + p_1 C_1^N + \frac{C_2^T + p_2 C_2^N}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + p_1 Q_1^N + \frac{Q_2^T + p_2 Q_2^N}{1 + r_1}C1T​+p1​C1N​+1+r1​C2T​+p2​C2N​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+p1​Q1N​+1+r1​Q2T​+p2​Q2N​​ becomes the economy's resource constraint:

C1T+C2T1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r1C_1^T + \frac{C_2^T}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r_1}C1T​+1+r1​C2T​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r1​Q2T​​

Equilibrium

An equilibrium requires four conditions:

  • Resource constraint
    • C1T+C2T1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r1C_1^T + \frac{C_2^T}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r_1}C1T​+1+r1​C2T​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r1​Q2T​​
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U11=U2p1=U311+r1=U4p2(1+r1)\frac{U_1}{1} = \frac{U_2}{p_1} = \frac{U_3}{\frac{1}{1 + r_1}} = \frac{U_4}{\frac{p_2}{(1 + r_1)}}1U1​​=p1​U2​​=1+r1​1​U3​​=(1+r1​)p2​​U4​​
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_1 = r^*r1​=r∗
  • Market clearing for nontradable goods
    • C1N=Q1NC_1^N = Q_1^NC1N​=Q1N​
    • C2N=Q2NC_2^N = Q_2^NC2N​=Q2N​

Solve Equilibrium

Using the derivative formula, d(ln⁡x)dx=1x\frac{d(\ln x)}{dx} = \frac{1}{x}dxd(lnx)​=x1​, we can get

  • U1=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C1T=1C1TU_1 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_1^T} = \frac{1}{C_1^T}U1​=∂C1T​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C1T​1​
  • U2=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C1N=1C1NU_2 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_1^N} = \frac{1}{C_1^N}U2​=∂C1N​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C1N​1​
  • U3=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C2T=1C2TU_3 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_2^T} = \frac{1}{C_2^T}U3​=∂C2T​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C2T​1​
  • U4=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C2N=1C2NU_4 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_2^N} = \frac{1}{C_2^N}U4​=∂C2N​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C2N​1​

Substitute the above to Optimality of the intertemporal allocation, we have:

  • −C1NC1T=−1p1-\frac{C_1^N}{C_1^T} = -\frac{1}{p_1}−C1T​C1N​​=−p1​1​ (3)
  • −C2TC1T=−(1+r1)-\frac{C_2^T}{C_1^T} = -(1 + r_1)−C1T​C2T​​=−(1+r1​) (4)
  • −C2NC1T=−1p2(1+r1)-\frac{C_2^N}{C_1^T} = -\frac{1}{p_2}(1 + r_1)−C1T​C2N​​=−p2​1​(1+r1​) (5)

From (4), we can obtain: C1T=12[(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r∗]C_1^T = \frac{1}{2}[(1 + r_0)B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r^*}]C1T​=21​[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r∗Q2T​​]

Then, we can subsequently derive:

  • C2T=12(1+r∗)[(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r∗]C_2^T = \frac{1}{2}(1 + r^*)[(1 + r_0)B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r^*}]C2T​=21​(1+r∗)[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r∗Q2T​​]
  • C1N=Q1NC_1^N = Q_1^NC1N​=Q1N​
  • C2N=Q2NC_2^N = Q_2^NC2N​=Q2N​
  • p1=C1TQ1Np_1 = \frac{C_1^T}{Q_1^N}p1​=Q1N​C1T​​
  • p2=C2TQ2N(1+r∗)p_2 = \frac{C_2^T}{Q_2^N}(1 + r^*)p2​=Q2N​C2T​​(1+r∗)

A sudden stop involves:

  • An improvement in the current account balance
  • A real exchange rate depreciation
  • A reduction in GDP

L10 - Sudden Stops and Unemployment

A Model of A Sudden Stop with Wage Rigidities
