Nominal wage rigidities create unemployment after a sudden stop:

  • a sudden stop generates a drop in the relative price of nontradables
  • Since wages do not go down, firms reduce both employment and the production of nontradables

Setup:

  • 2 Periods
  • Representative HH and representative firm
    • the household owns the firm
    • The firm produces nontradables with labor input hired from the household
  • tradable and nontradable consumption goods
  • There is a single asset, a bond, in this world (HH holds B0B_0B0​ units at beginning)
  • Endowment: The household is endowed with:
    • Q1TQ_1^TQ1T​ units of tradables and Q1NQ_1^NQ1N​ units of nontradables in period 1
    • Q2TQ_2^TQ2T​ units of tradables and Q2NQ_2^NQ2N​ units of nontradables in period 2
  • Consumption: The household's consumption choices are
    • C1TC_1^TC1T​ for tradables and C1NC_1^NC1N​ for nontradables in period 1
    • C2TC_2^TC2T​ for tradables and C2NC_2^NC2N​ for nontradables in period 2
  • Labor endowment (which can be used in the production of nontradable goods):
    • The household is endowed with hˉ\bar{h}hˉ units of labor in each period
    • (h1,h2)(h_1, h_2)(h1​,h2​): The amounts of labor actually hired by the firm in periods 1 and 2
      • ht≤hˉh_t \leq \bar{h}ht​≤hˉ for t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2
  • Price of goods are determined in equilibrium:
    • p1p_1p1​ = price of nontradables relative to that of tradables in period 1
    • p2p_2p2​ = price of nontradables relative to that of tradables in period 2

Nominal Prices

  • The prices PtNP_t^NPtN​, t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2, of nontradables are determined in equilibrium by domestic demand and supply conditions
  • The prices PtTP_t^TPtT​, t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2, of tradables are determined by the LOOP (PtT=εtPt∗P_t^T = \varepsilon_t P_t^{*}PtT​=εt​Pt∗​)
    • nominal exchange rate εt\varepsilon_tεt​ as an exogenously given policy decision
    • take Pt∗P_t^{*}Pt∗​ as given (small economy)
    • assume P1∗=P2∗=1P_1^{*} = P_2^{*} = 1P1∗​=P2∗​=1 (for simplicity)
    • Therefore, PtT=εtP_t^T = \varepsilon_tPtT​=εt​ for t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2

The Firm's Problem

The firm owned by the household produces nontradable goods in this economy

  • Labor input: (h1,h2)(h_1, h_2)(h1​,h2​)
  • Wage per unit of labor: (W1,W2)(W_1, W_2)(W1​,W2​)
  • Production technology: QtN=(ht)αQ_t^N = (h_t)^\alphaQtN​=(ht​)α where α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1)

Firm's profit maximization problem in period t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2:

  • max⁡ht≥0[PtNQtN(ht)−Wtht]\max_{h_t \geq 0}[ P_t^N Q_t^N(h_t) - W_t h_t]maxht​≥0​[PtN​QtN​(ht​)−Wt​ht​] (1)
    • PtNQtN(ht)P_t^N Q_t^N(h_t)PtN​QtN​(ht​): Revenues
    • WthtW_t h_tWt​ht​: Labor Costs

Divide the profit function in problem (1) by PtTP_t^TPtT​ to obtain

  • max⁡ht≥0[(PtNPtT)QtN(ht)−(WtPtT)ht]\max_{h_t \geq 0} \left[ \left( \frac{P_t^N}{P_t^T} \right) Q_t^N(h_t) - \left( \frac{W_t}{P_t^T} \right) h_t \right]maxht​≥0​[(PtT​PtN​​)QtN​(ht​)−(PtT​Wt​​)ht​] (2)
    or
  • max⁡ht≥0[ptQtN(ht)−wtht]\max_{h_t \geq 0} [ p_t Q_t^N(h_t) - w_t h_t ]maxht​≥0​[pt​QtN​(ht​)−wt​ht​],
    where
    • pt≡PtNPtTp_t \equiv \frac{P_t^N}{P_t^T}pt​≡PtT​PtN​​: price of nontradables relative to that of tradables
    • wt≡WtPtTw_t \equiv \frac{W_t}{P_t^T}wt​≡PtT​Wt​​: real wage

Substituting in the production function we arrive at: max⁡ht≥0[pt(ht)α−wtht]\max_{h_t \geq 0} [p_t (h_t)^\alpha - w_t h_t]maxht​≥0​[pt​(ht​)α−wt​ht​]

Πt≡max⁡ht≥0[pt(ht)α−wtht]\Pi_t \equiv \max_{h_t \geq 0} [ p_t (h_t)^\alpha - w_t h_t ]Πt​≡maxht​≥0​[pt​(ht​)α−wt​ht​]

  • pt(ht)αp_t (h_t)^\alphapt​(ht​)α: Revenues
  • wthtw_t h_twt​ht​: Labor Costs

The firm's optimal choice of employment satisfies the FOC:

MP=d(pt(ht)α)dht=ptα(ht)α−1=wt=d(wtht)dht=MCMP = \frac{d (p_t (h_t)^\alpha)}{d h_t} = p_t \alpha (h_t)^{\alpha-1} = w_t = \frac{d (w_t h_t)}{d h_t} = MCMP=dht​d(pt​(ht​)α)​=pt​α(ht​)α−1=wt​=dht​d(wt​ht​)​=MC

The condition ptα(ht)α−1=wtp_t \alpha (h_t)^{\alpha-1} = w_tpt​α(ht​)α−1=wt​ is also sufficient for profit maximization as:

  • the production function htαh_t^\alphahtα​ is strictly concave, and therefore
  • the profit function pthtα−wthtp_t h_t^\alpha - w_t h_tpt​htα​−wt​ht​ is strictly concave

Downward Nominal Wage Rigidities

If nominal wages are flexible, they adjust to achieve full employment. In that case, we have: h1=h2=hˉh_1 = h_2 = \bar{h}h1​=h2​=hˉ

However, an important assumption of our model today are downward nominal wage rigidities

  • Nominal wages do not adjust downwards in the short-run
  • Thus the labor market may not clear. We can have h1<hˉh_1 < \bar{h}h1​<hˉ, h2<hˉh_2 < \bar{h}h2​<hˉ

Formally, taking W0W_0W0​ as exogenously given, we assume:

  • downward nominal wage rigidity W2≥W1≥W0W_2 \geq W_1 \geq W_0W2​≥W1​≥W0​
  • labor market slackness conditions (W2−W1)(hˉ−h2)=(W1−W0)(hˉ−h1)=0(W_2 - W_1)(\bar{h} - h_2) = (W_1 - W_0)(\bar{h} - h_1) = 0(W2​−W1​)(hˉ−h2​)=(W1​−W0​)(hˉ−h1​)=0

In fact, to simplify our analysis, we now assume that:

  • ε1=ε2=εˉ\varepsilon_1 = \varepsilon_2 = \bar{\varepsilon}ε1​=ε2​=εˉ (fixed exchange rate regime / currency peg)
  • Nominal wages are rigid: W2=W1=W0W_2 = W_1 = W_0W2​=W1​=W0​
  • These assumptions imply that real wages are rigid: wˉ≡w1=W1P1T=W0εˉ=w2=W2P2T=W0εˉ\bar{w} \equiv w_1 = \frac{W_1}{P_1^T} = \frac{W_0}{\bar{\varepsilon}} = w_2 = \frac{W_2}{P_2^T} = \frac{W_0}{\bar{\varepsilon}}wˉ≡w1​=P1T​W1​​=εˉW0​​=w2​=P2T​W2​​=εˉW0​​

Household's Budget Constraints

The BCs are expressed in tradable goods as the unit of measure

Therefore, we have:

  • C1T+p1C1N+B1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+w1h1+Π1C_1^T + p_1 C_1^N + B_1 = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + w_1 h_1 + \Pi_1C1T​+p1​C1N​+B1​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+w1​h1​+Π1​ (3)
  • C2T+p2C2N=(1+r1)B1+Q2T+w2h2+Π2C_2^T + p_2 C_2^N = (1 + r_1) B_1 + Q_2^T + w_2 h_2 + \Pi_2C2T​+p2​C2N​=(1+r1​)B1​+Q2T​+w2​h2​+Π2​ (4)
  • hth_tht​ denotes the actual amount of labor employed by the firm in period ttt
  • w1h1+Π1=p1Q1Nw_1 h_1 + \Pi_1 = p_1 Q_1^Nw1​h1​+Π1​=p1​Q1N​
  • w2h2+Π2=p2Q2Nw_2 h_2 + \Pi_2 = p_2 Q_2^Nw2​h2​+Π2​=p2​Q2N​

(3) & (4) yield the intertemporal budget constraint:

C1T+p1C1N+C2T+p2C2N1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+p1Q1N+Q2T+p2Q2N1+r1C_1^T + p_1 C_1^N + \frac{C_2^T + p_2 C_2^N}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + p_1 Q_1^N + \frac{Q_2^T + p_2 Q_2^N}{1 + r_1}C1T​+p1​C1N​+1+r1​C2T​+p2​C2N​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+p1​Q1N​+1+r1​Q2T​+p2​Q2N​​

Resource Constraint

Market Clearing Conditions (all the nontradables are consumed within the country):

  • C1N=Q1N=(h1)αC_{1}^{N}=Q_{1}^{N}=(h_1)^\alphaC1N​=Q1N​=(h1​)α
  • C2N=Q2N=(h2)αC_{2}^{N}=Q_{2}^{N}=(h_2)^\alphaC2N​=Q2N​=(h2​)α

Therefore, C1T+p1C1N+C2T+p2C2N1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+p1Q1N+Q2T+p2Q2N1+r1C_1^T + p_1 C_1^N + \frac{C_2^T + p_2 C_2^N}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + p_1 Q_1^N + \frac{Q_2^T + p_2 Q_2^N}{1 + r_1}C1T​+p1​C1N​+1+r1​C2T​+p2​C2N​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+p1​Q1N​+1+r1​Q2T​+p2​Q2N​​ becomes the economy's resource constraint:

C1T+C2T1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r1C_1^T + \frac{C_2^T}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r_1}C1T​+1+r1​C2T​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r1​Q2T​​

Equilibrium

An equilibrium requires five conditions:

  • Resource constraint
    • C1T+C2T1+r1=(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r1C_1^T + \frac{C_2^T}{1 + r_1} = (1 + r_0) B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r_1}C1T​+1+r1​C2T​​=(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r1​Q2T​​ (5)
  • Optimality of the intertemporal allocation
    • U11=U2p1=U311+r1=U4p2(1+r1)\frac{U_1}{1} = \frac{U_2}{p_1} = \frac{U_3}{\frac{1}{1 + r_1}} = \frac{U_4}{\frac{p_2}{(1 + r_1)}}1U1​​=p1​U2​​=1+r1​1​U3​​=(1+r1​)p2​​U4​​ (6)
  • Interest rate parity condition
    • r1=r∗r_1 = r^*r1​=r∗ (7)
  • Market clearing for nontradable goods (8)
    • C1N=Q1N=(h1)αC_{1}^{N}=Q_{1}^{N}=(h_1)^\alphaC1N​=Q1N​=(h1​)α
    • C2N=Q2N=(h2)αC_{2}^{N}=Q_{2}^{N}=(h_2)^\alphaC2N​=Q2N​=(h2​)α
  • Firm's optimization conditions (9)
    • p1α(h1)α−1=wˉp_1 \alpha (h_1)^{\alpha-1} = \bar{w}p1​α(h1​)α−1=wˉ
    • p2α(h2)α−1=wˉp_2 \alpha (h_2)^{\alpha-1} = \bar{w}p2​α(h2​)α−1=wˉ

Solve Equilibrium

Steps

Using the derivative formula, d(ln⁡x)dx=1x\frac{d(\ln x)}{dx} = \frac{1}{x}dxd(lnx)​=x1​, we can get

  • U1=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C1T=1C1TU_1 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_1^T} = \frac{1}{C_1^T}U1​=∂C1T​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C1T​1​
  • U2=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C1N=1C1NU_2 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_1^N} = \frac{1}{C_1^N}U2​=∂C1N​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C1N​1​
  • U3=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C2T=1C2TU_3 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_2^T} = \frac{1}{C_2^T}U3​=∂C2T​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C2T​1​
  • U4=∂(ln⁡C1T+ln⁡C1N+ln⁡C2T+ln⁡C2N)∂C2N=1C2NU_4 = \frac{\partial (\ln C_1^T + \ln C_1^N + \ln C_2^T + \ln C_2^N)}{\partial C_2^N} = \frac{1}{C_2^N}U4​=∂C2N​∂(lnC1T​+lnC1N​+lnC2T​+lnC2N​)​=C2N​1​

Substitute the above to Optimality of the intertemporal allocation, we have:

  • −C1NC1T=−1p1-\frac{C_1^N}{C_1^T} = -\frac{1}{p_1}−C1T​C1N​​=−p1​1​ (10)
  • −C2TC1T=−(1+r1)-\frac{C_2^T}{C_1^T} = -(1 + r_1)−C1T​C2T​​=−(1+r1​) (11)
  • −C2NC1T=−1p2(1+r1)-\frac{C_2^N}{C_1^T} = -\frac{1}{p_2}(1 + r_1)−C1T​C2N​​=−p2​1​(1+r1​) (12)

From (11), we can obtain: C1T=12[(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r∗]C_1^T = \frac{1}{2}[(1 + r_0)B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r^*}]C1T​=21​[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r∗Q2T​​]

Then, we can subsequently derive:

  • C1T=12[(1+r0)B0+Q1T+Q2T1+r∗]C_1^T = \frac{1}{2}[(1 + r_0)B_0 + Q_1^T + \frac{Q_2^T}{1 + r^*}]C1T​=21​[(1+r0​)B0​+Q1T​+1+r∗Q2T​​]
  • C2T=(1+r∗)C1TC_2^T = (1 + r^*)C_1^TC2T​=(1+r∗)C1T​
  • p1=(wˉα)α(C1T)1−αp_1 = \left( \frac{\bar{w}}{\alpha} \right)^\alpha (C_1^T)^{1-\alpha}p1​=(αwˉ​)α(C1T​)1−α
  • p2=(wˉα)α(C2T)1−αp_2 = \left( \frac{\bar{w}}{\alpha} \right)^\alpha (C_2^T)^{1-\alpha}p2​=(αwˉ​)α(C2T​)1−α
  • h1=(αp1wˉ)11−αh_1 = \left( \frac{\alpha p_1}{\bar{w}} \right)^{\frac{1}{1-\alpha}}h1​=(wˉαp1​​)1−α1​
  • h2=(αp2wˉ)11−αh_2 = \left( \frac{\alpha p_2}{\bar{w}} \right)^{\frac{1}{1-\alpha}}h2​=(wˉαp2​​)1−α1​
  • C1N=(h1)αC_1^N = (h_1)^\alphaC1N​=(h1​)α
  • C2N=(h2)αC_2^N = (h_2)^\alphaC2N​=(h2​)α

A sudden stop involves:

  • An improvement in the current account balance
  • An increase in the unemployment rate
  • A moderate depreciation of the real exchange rate
    • The real exchange rate would depreciate more if nominal wages went down
  • A reduction in GDP

L11 - International Capital Market Integration

Saving-Investment Correlations

Feldstein and Horioka (1980) document that national saving rates are highly correlated with investment rates

  • 16 industrialized countries
  • Data on average saving-to-GDP and investment-to-GDP rates during 1960-1974
  • Cross-country OLS regression: (IGDP)i=α+β(SGDP)i+vi(\frac{I}{GDP})_i = \alpha + \beta (\frac{S}{GDP})_i + v_i(GDPI​)i​=α+β(GDPS​)i​+vi​
    • iii indicates a country
    • α=0.035\alpha = 0.035α=0.035
    • β=0.887\beta = 0.887β=0.887 (strong positive correlation)
    • R2=0.91R^2 = 0.91R2=0.91 (91% of cross-country variation in IGDP\frac{I}{GDP}GDPI​ explained by variations in SGDP\frac{S}{GDP}GDPS​)

  • Feldstein and Horioka (1980) argued:
    • If capital was highly mobile across countries, then the correlation between saving and investment should be ≈ 0
    • In their view, above empirical findings thus evidence low capital mobility
  • To understand their position, recall that CA(r)=S(r)−I(r)CA(r) = S(r) - I(r)CA(r)=S(r)−I(r)
  • degree of capital mobility - measuring the comovement of saving and investment

Feldstein and Horioka (1980)

In a closed economy, S=IS = IS=I

  • Comovement of SSS and III
  • The lack of (cross-border) capital mobility -> high correlation between SSS and III
  • Regressing (IGDP)\left( \frac{I}{GDP} \right)(GDPI​) on (SGDP)\left( \frac{S}{GDP} \right)(GDPS​) -> β\betaβ is positive and significant if countries are closed

In an open economy, SSS and III do not have to move together

  • We expect that β\betaβ is insignificant under free capital mobility

For the 16 industrialized countries (cross-country analysis):

  • During the period 1960-1974, β\betaβ = 0.887
  • For the later period 1974-1990, β\betaβ = 0.495

For the U.S. (time-series analysis):

  • During the period 1955-1979, β\betaβ = 1.05
  • For the later period 1980-1987, β\betaβ = 0.03

Feldstein and Horioka -> these results imply that the mobility of capital has increased over time

However: Observing high correlations between S and I need not be informative about the degree of international capital market integration

A high correlation between S and I doesn't necessarily imply that an economy is financially closed!

Counterexample 1: Same shock shifts both the saving and the investment schedule

  • Small open production economy with perfect capital mobility
  • Qt=AtF(It−1)Q_t = A_tF(I_{t-1})Qt​=At​F(It−1​) for t=1,2t = 1, 2t=1,2
  • Permanent positive productivity shock: ΔA1≫ΔA2>0\Delta A_1 \gg \Delta A_2 > 0ΔA1​≫ΔA2​>0
    • A2↑A_2 \uparrowA2​↑: I shifts right
    • A2↑A_2 \uparrowA2​↑: Π2↑\Pi_2 \uparrowΠ2​↑
    • A1↑A_1 \uparrowA1​↑: Π1↑\Pi_1 \uparrowΠ1​↑
    • ΔA1≫ΔA2\Delta A_1 \gg \Delta A_2ΔA1​≫ΔA2​: plausible that Π1\Pi_1Π1​ increases more than Π2\Pi_2Π2​
    • Thus S shifts right as the consumption-smoothing HH saves more in period 1
  • Despite free capital mobility, the shock generates a spurious comovement of saving and investment

Counterexample 2: Large country effects

  • Large open economy with perfect capital mobility.
  • Shock that shifts saving schedule to the right.
    • domestic CA schedule shifts to the right
    • →\to→ world interest rate falls
    • →\to→ domestic investment schedule shifts to the right.
  • Despite free capital mobility, the shock generates a spurious comovement of saving and investment

The Covered Interest Rate Parity

An alternative way to measure capital mobility is to check the covered interest rate parity (CIP).

Idea: Rates of return on risk-free assets should be equal across countries.

Setup:

  • iti_tit​ = domestic (U.S.) interest rate in period ttt
  • it∗i_t^*it∗​ = foreign (German) interest rate in period ttt
  • εt\varepsilon_tεt​ = spot exchange rate in period ttt = the dollar price of 1 euro in period ttt
  • εt+1\varepsilon_{t+1}εt+1​ = spot exchange rate in period t+1t + 1t+1

Consider the following two investment strategies:

  • Invest one dollar in domestic bonds with interest rate iti_tit​
    • Returns (1+it)(1 + i_t)(1+it​) dollars in period t+1t + 1t+1.
  • Invest one dollar in foreign bonds with interest rate it∗i_t^*it∗​
    • First, exchange the dollar to euros
    • In period ttt, 1 euro costs εt\varepsilon_tεt​ dollars. Therefore, exchanging 1 dollar gives you 1εt\frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}εt​1​ euros
    • In period t+1t + 1t+1, the 1εt\frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}εt​1​ euros invested in foreign bonds returns (1+it∗)1εt\left( 1 + i_t^* \right) \frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​1​ euros
    • Converting these euros back to dollars, you get (1+it∗)εt+1εt\left( 1 + i_t^* \right) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​ dollars

One might therefore be tempted to conclude that we must have (1+it)=(1+it∗)εt+1εt(1 + i_t) = (1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)=(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​

Otherwise, an arbitrage opportunity appears to be present:

  • (1+it)>(1+it∗)εt+1εt(1 + i_t) > (1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)>(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​ (borrow abroad and invest at home)
  • (1+it)<(1+it∗)εt+1εt(1 + i_t) < (1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)<(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​ (borrow at home and invest abroad)

Snag:

  • The future exchange rate εt+1\varepsilon_{t+1}εt+1​ is unknown in period ttt
  • Investing abroad involves exchange rate risk
  • While the return (1+it)(1 + i_t)(1+it​) is certain, the return (1+it∗)εt+1εt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​ is uncertain. The two returns are not directly comparable

Forward Exchange Rate (CID & CIP)

Forward contracts are designed to overcome exchange rate risks.

Forward Exchange Contract: A contract made in period ttt to exchange currencies in period t+1t + 1t+1 at the pre-agreed rate FtF_tFt​.

  • FtF_tFt​ = forward rate = dollar price in period ttt of €1 delivered and paid for in period t+1t + 1t+1
  • A forward contract agreed upon in period ttt involves no money exchange in period ttt (only in period t+1t + 1t+1)
  • Return from the strategy 1: (1+it)(1 + i_t)(1+it​)
  • Return from the strategy 2 with a forward contract: (1+it∗)Ftεt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​
    • This return is certain and comparable to strategy 1’s return

The difference (1+it)−(1+it∗)Ftεt(1 + i_t) - (1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)−(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​ is called the covered interest rate differential (CID).

  • “Covered” because the forward contract covers the investor against exchange rate risk.
  • If the covered interest differential is zero then we say that covered interest rate parity (CIP) holds.

Covered Interest Rate Parity: Under free capital mobility, (1+it)=(1+it∗)Ftεt(1 + i_t) = (1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)=(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​ holds.

Proof

Suppose that (1+it)<(1+it∗)Ftεt(1 + i_t) < (1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)<(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​. Then the following transaction gives investors an arbitrage opportunity

  • In period ttt:
    • Borrow 1 dollar at home at the interest rate iti_tit​
    • Exchange the 1 dollar to 1εt\frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}εt​1​ euros
    • Invest the 1εt\frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}εt​1​ euros in foreign bonds
    • Enter a forward contract to exchange (1+it∗)1εt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​1​ euros next period
  • In period t+1t + 1t+1:
    • Receive (1+it∗)1εt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​1​ euros from your foreign investment
    • Execute the forward contract to receive (1+it∗)Ftεt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​ dollars for those euros
    • You materialize a profit of (1+it∗)Ftεt−(1+it)>0(1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t} - (1 + i_t) > 0(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​−(1+it​)>0
  • Under free capital mobility investors exploit all arbitrage opportunities, so the above inequality cannot hold.

Takeaway:

  • If there is no default risk for bonds and forward contracts, the CIP should hold if there is free capital mobility
  • Therefore, non-zero covered interest-rate differentials indicate a lack of free capital mobility

Empirical Evidence on CIDs

(1+itUS)−(1+itCN)Ftεt(1 + i_t^{US}) - (1 + i_t^{CN}) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+itUS​)−(1+itCN​)εt​Ft​​

  • There are large deviations from covered interest parity (3.1 percentage points on average)
  • In the last 5 years of the sample, the CID fell to 2.1 percentage points on average (still sizable)
  • Large CIDs are a sign of impediments to capital flows
  • A negative CID indicates impediments to capital inflows into China
    • Chinese wanting to borrow from abroad to invest at home but not being able to
  • A positive CID indicates impediments to capital outflows from China to the U.S.
    • Chinese wanting to save abroad but not being able to

Uncovered Interest Rate Parity (UIP)

Start from the CIP equation (1+it)=(1+it∗)Ftεt(1 + i_t) = (1 + i_t^*) \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)=(1+it∗​)εt​Ft​​

  • Replace the forward rate FtF_tFt​ with the expected spot exchange rate Et(εt+1)E_t(\varepsilon_{t+1})Et​(εt+1​)
  • This yields the uncovered interest rate parity equation

Uncovered Interest Rate Parity: If (1+it)=(1+it∗)Et(εt+1)εt(1 + i_t) = (1 + i_t^*)\frac{E_t(\varepsilon_{t+1})}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it​)=(1+it∗​)εt​Et​(εt+1​)​ then we say that uncovered interest rate parity (UIP) holds

  • Even under free capital mobility, UIP might not hold
  • This is because Ft=Et(εt+1)F_t = E_t (\varepsilon_{t+1})Ft​=Et​(εt+1​) does not always hold (both in theory and in the data)

Forward Premium Puzzle

  • The so-called forward premium puzzle indicates that UIP is strongly rejected by the data:
  • Conditional on CIP holding, UIP holds if and only if Etεt+1εt=FtεtE_t\frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t} = \frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t}Et​εt​εt+1​​=εt​Ft​​
    • If Ft>εtF_t > \varepsilon_tFt​>εt​ we say that the foreign currency is at a premium in the forward market
    • If UIP holds then the domestic currency is expected to depreciate when the foreign currency trades at a premium in the forward market
  • CIP holds pretty well in the data.
  • Thus, if UIP holds as well then the OLS regression εt+1εt=a+bFtεt+μt+1\frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t} = a + b\frac{F_t}{\varepsilon_t} + \mu_{t+1}εt​εt+1​​=a+bεt​Ft​​+μt+1​ should yield a=0a = 0a=0 and b=1b = 1b=1
  • However, e.g., Burnside (2018) estimates a=0.00055a = 0.00055a=0.00055 and b=−0.75b = -0.75b=−0.75 as cross-country average estimates of the USD against currencies of 10 industrialized countries for January 1976 - March 2018.
  • This forward premium puzzle indicates UIP is strongly rejected by the data.

Offshore-Onshore Interest Rate Differentials

Eurocurrency deposits are foreign currency deposits in a market other than the home market of the foreign currency

  • e.g.: eurodollar deposits = dollar deposits outside the U.S.

offshore-onshore interest rate differential = it∗−iti_t^* - i_tit∗​−it​

  • it∗i_t^*it∗​: offshore interest rate in period t on a USD deposit
  • iti_tit​: onshore interest rate in period t on a USD deposit

Under free capital mobility, the offshore-onshore differential should be zero.

This indicates:

  • free capital mobility during 1990-2008
    • Near zero offshore-onshore differential
  • impediments in the 1980s and post 2008
    • attributed to post-GFC regulations
    • prevent financial institutions to exploit the
  • arbitrage opportunities

The Real Interest Rate Differential

Can the real interest rate differential rt−rt∗r_t - r_t^*rt​−rt∗​ be a measure of free capital mobility?

Short Answer: In general, not a good measure

Consider a two-period small open economy with free capital mobility and two assets:

  • b1b_1b1​ = units of a domestic real bond
    • 1 unit pays (1+r1)(1 + r_1)(1+r1​) domestic consumption baskets in t=2t = 2t=2
  • b1∗b_1^*b1∗​ = units of a foreign real bond
    • 1 unit pays (1+r1∗)(1 + r_1^*)(1+r1∗​) foreign consumption baskets in t=2t = 2t=2

Real exchange rate: εt=εtPt∗Pt\varepsilon_t = \frac{\varepsilon_t P_t^*}{P_t}εt​=Pt​εt​Pt∗​​

Budget constraint in period 1: C1+b1+e1b1∗=Q1C_1 + b_1 + e_1 b_1^* = Q_1C1​+b1​+e1​b1∗​=Q1​ (1)

Budget constraint in period 2: C2=(1+r1)b1+(1+r1∗)e2b1∗+Q2C_2 = (1 + r_1)b_1 + (1 + r_1^*)e_2b_1^* + Q_2C2​=(1+r1​)b1​+(1+r1∗​)e2​b1∗​+Q2​ (2)

Utility: U(C1)+U(C2)U(C_1) + U(C_2)U(C1​)+U(C2​)

Household's optimization problem:

  • max⁡C1,C2U(C1)+U(C2)\max_{C_1, C_2} U(C_1) + U(C_2)maxC1​,C2​​U(C1​)+U(C2​) s.t. (1) & (2),
  • max⁡b1,b1∗U(Q1−b1−e1b1∗)+U((1+r1)b1+(1+r1∗)e2b1∗+Q2)\max_{b_1, b_1^*} U(Q_1 - b_1 - e_1b_1^*) + U((1 + r_1)b_1 + (1 + r_1^*)e_2b_1^* + Q_2)maxb1​,b1∗​​U(Q1​−b1​−e1​b1∗​)+U((1+r1​)b1​+(1+r1∗​)e2​b1∗​+Q2​)

FOCs:

  • −U′(C1)+(1+r1)U′(C2)=0-U'(C_1) + (1 + r_1)U'(C_2) = 0−U′(C1​)+(1+r1​)U′(C2​)=0
  • −e1U′(C1)+(1+r1∗)e2U′(C2)=0-e_1U'(C_1) + (1 + r_1^*)e_2U'(C_2) = 0−e1​U′(C1​)+(1+r1∗​)e2​U′(C2​)=0

Solving each FOC for U′(C1)U′(C2)\frac{U'(C_1)}{U'(C_2)}U′(C2​)U′(C1​)​ and equating the results yields: (1+r1)=(1+r1∗)e2e1(1 + r_1) = (1 + r_1^*) \frac{e_2}{e_1}(1+r1​)=(1+r1∗​)e1​e2​​

Thus despite free capital mobility, real interest rate parity fails as long as e2e1≠1\frac{e_2}{e_1} \neq 1e1​e2​​=1.

L12 - Inflationary Finance & BoP Crises

How sustained fiscal deficits combined with a currency peg can end in a balance of payment crisis.

Fiscal Deficits, Inflation, and the Exchange Rate Model

a model with the following building blocks:

  • more than 2 periods
  • an interest-elastic demand for money
  • purchasing power parity
  • interest rate parity
  • the government budget constraint

Demand and Supply for Money

We assume that households have a demand for money

  • Money is non-interest-bearing
  • People still hold money (medium of exchange)

Period-t money demand function: MtdPt=L(Ct,it)\frac{M^d_t}{P_t} = L(C_t, i_t)Pt​Mtd​​=L(Ct​,it​)

  • where L is a liquidity preference function
  • L is increasing in period-t consumption CtC_tCt​
  • L is decreasing in the nominal interest rate iti_tit​
    • The nominal interest rate iti_tit​ on interest-bearing liquid assets (time deposits, ...) is the opportunity cost of holding money

We assume that Ct=CC_t = CCt​=C for all t, thus MtdPt=L(C,it)\frac{M^d_t}{P_t} = L(C, i_t)Pt​Mtd​​=L(C,it​)

  • MtM_tMt​ denotes the nominal supply of money

The equilibrium condition in the money market is MtPt=L(C,it)\frac{M_t}{P_t} = L(C, i_t)Pt​Mt​​=L(C,it​) (1)

Purchasing Power Parity

There is a single tradable good

Absolute purchasing power parity holds: Pt=εtPt∗P_t = \varepsilon_t P_t^*Pt​=εt​Pt∗​

For simplicity, we assume Pt∗=1P_t^* = 1Pt∗​=1 for all t. Thus Pt=εtP_t = \varepsilon_tPt​=εt​ and money market clearing condition (1) becomes: Mtεt=L(C,it)\frac{M_t}{\varepsilon_t} = L(C, i_t)εt​Mt​​=L(C,it​)

Interest Parity Condition

Let it∗i_t^*it∗​ denote the foreign nominal interest rate in period t

  • We assume that it∗=i∗i_t^* = i^*it∗​=i∗ for all t
  • We assume that there is free capital mobility
  • We assume that there is no uncertainty
    • E.g., at time t the HH knows the entire future path of nominal exchange rates (εt,εt+1,εt+2,...)(\varepsilon_t, \varepsilon_{t+1}, \varepsilon_{t+2}, ...)(εt​,εt+1​,εt+2​,...)
  • We then get the interest parity condition: 1+it=(1+it∗)εt+1εt1 + i_t = (1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}1+it​=(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​

There can be no arbitrage opportunity between domestic ($) and foreign (€) bonds

  • Gross return of investing $1 in a domestic bond: (1+it)(1 + i_t)(1+it​)
  • Gross return of investing $1 in a foreign bond: (1+it∗)εt+1εt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​
    • $1 buys €1εt\frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}εt​1​ in period t
    • Investing €1εt\frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}εt​1​ in foreign bonds pays €(1+it∗)1εt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​1​ in period t + 1
    • €(1+it∗)1εt(1 + i_t^*) \frac{1}{\varepsilon_t}(1+it∗​)εt​1​ buy ((1+it∗)εt+1εt)((1 + i_t^*) \frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t})((1+it∗​)εt​εt+1​​) in period t + 1

Government Budget Constraint

The period t government budget constraint is:

εtBtg+PtGt=(1+i∗)εtBt−1g+PtTt+(Mt−Mt−1)\varepsilon_t B_t^g + P_t G_t = (1 + i^*) \varepsilon_t B_{t-1}^g + P_t T_t + (M_t - M_{t-1})εt​Btg​+Pt​Gt​=(1+i∗)εt​Bt−1g​+Pt​Tt​+(Mt​−Mt−1​)

  • Government consumption GtG_tGt​ and tax revenue TtT_tTt​ are measured in units of goods
  • (Mt−Mt−1)(M_t - M_{t-1})(Mt​−Mt−1​) is income from money creation

Dividing by PtP_tPt​ and rearranging yields:

Btg=Bt−1g+Mt−Mt−1Pt−(Gt−Tt−i∗Bt−1g)B_t^g = B_{t-1}^g + \frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{P_t} - (G_t - T_t - i^* B_{t-1}^g)Btg​=Bt−1g​+Pt​Mt​−Mt−1​​−(Gt​−Tt​−i∗Bt−1g​) (2)

  • Mt−Mt−1Pt\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{P_t}Pt​Mt​−Mt−1​​: seignorage revenue
  • (Gt−Tt−i∗Bt−1g)(G_t - T_t - i^* B_{t-1}^g)(Gt​−Tt​−i∗Bt−1g​): secondary fiscal deficit

Let DEFt=(Gt−Tt)−i∗Bt−1gDEF_t = (G_t - T_t) - i^* B_{t-1}^gDEFt​=(Gt​−Tt​)−i∗Bt−1g​

Then, using Pt=εtP_t = \varepsilon_tPt​=εt​, we have:

Btg=Bt−1g+Mt−Mt−1εt−DEFtB_t^g = B_{t-1}^g + \frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} - DEF_tBtg​=Bt−1g​+εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​−DEFt​ (3)

If DEFt>0DEF_t > 0DEFt​>0, then:

  • the government creates money (Mt−Mt−1>0M_t - M_{t-1} > 0Mt​−Mt−1​>0) and/or
  • the government's asset position declines (Btg<Bt−1gB_t^g < B_{t-1}^gBtg​<Bt−1g​)

Fiscal Deficits and the Sustainability of Currency Pegs

First, consider a fixed exchange rate regime:

  • εt=ε\varepsilon_t = \varepsilonεt​=ε for all t
  • Government intervenes in the forex market to keep ε\varepsilonε fixed
  • Money supply MtM_tMt​ becomes an endogenous variable because the central bank must stand ready to exchange domestic for foreign currency at the fixed rate ε\varepsilonε

By PPP:

  • Pt=εP_t = \varepsilonPt​=ε for all t
  • stop high inflation -> pegging its currency to a low-inflation country
    • Argentina did that in 1991 by pegging the peso to the USD
  • exchange rate-based stabilization program is however only a short-lived remedy to high inflation if not accompanied by fiscal reform

By the interest parity condition: it=i∗i_t = i^*it​=i∗

Money market clearing condition: Mt=εL(C,i∗)M_t = \varepsilon L(C, i^*)Mt​=εL(C,i∗)

  • Money supply is constant in equilibrium
  • Revenue from seignorage is zero

The government budget constraint simplifies to:

Btg=Bt−1g+Mt−Mt−1ε−DEFt=Bt−1g−DEFtB_t^g = B_{t-1}^g + \frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon} - DEF_t = B_{t-1}^g - DEF_tBtg​=Bt−1g​+εMt​−Mt−1​​−DEFt​=Bt−1g​−DEFt​

  • Fiscal deficit is financed by running down government asset holdings

Suppose that:

  • there is an upper limit on the size of the public debt Btg≥DB_t^g \geq DBtg​≥D for all t, where D ≤ 0 is the debt limit
  • DEFt=DEF>0DEF_t = DEF > 0DEFt​=DEF>0 for all t

Then at some point, to avoid Btg<DB_t^g < DBtg​<D, the government must:

  • reduce its fiscal deficit (e.g. DEFt=0DEF_t = 0DEFt​=0 for all t ≥ T) OR
  • default on its debt OR
  • abandon the currency peg

Such a situation is called a balance of payments crisis

Fiscal Consequences of an Unexpected Devaluation

Scenario: Suppose that in period t the central bank unexpectedly devalues the currency

  • εt−1=ε\varepsilon_{t-1} = \varepsilonεt−1​=ε but εt=ε′>ε\varepsilon_t = \varepsilon ' > \varepsilonεt​=ε′>ε

By PPP, Pt−1=εP_{t-1} = \varepsilonPt−1​=ε and Pt=ε′P_t = \varepsilon 'Pt​=ε′

  • The devaluation causes inflation

By interest parity, it−1=it=i∗i_{t-1} = i_t = i^*it−1​=it​=i∗:

  • In every period the HH expects the nominal exchange rate to remain unchanged:
    • In t - 1, the HH (wrongly) expects that εt−1=εt=ε\varepsilon_{t-1} = \varepsilon_t = \varepsilonεt−1​=εt​=ε
    • In t, the HH expects εt=εt+1=ε′\varepsilon_t = \varepsilon_{t+1} = \varepsilon 'εt​=εt+1​=ε′

The demand for nominal money balances increases from Mt−1d=εL(C,i∗)M_{t-1}^d = \varepsilon L(C, i^*)Mt−1d​=εL(C,i∗) to Mtd=ε′L(C,i∗)M_t^d = \varepsilon 'L(C, i^*)Mtd​=ε′L(C,i∗)

The period-t government budget constraint becomes:

Btg=Bt−1g+Mt−Mt−1εt−DEFtB_t^g = B_{t-1}^g + \frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} - DEF_tBtg​=Bt−1g​+εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​−DEFt​

Btg=Bt−1g+ε′L(C,i∗)−εL(C,i∗)ε′−DEFB_t^g = B_{t-1}^g + \frac{\varepsilon 'L(C, i^*) - \varepsilon L(C, i^*)}{\varepsilon '} - DEFBtg​=Bt−1g​+ε′ε′L(C,i∗)−εL(C,i∗)​−DEF

  • ε′L(C,i∗)−εL(C,i∗)ε′>0\frac{\varepsilon 'L(C, i^*) - \varepsilon L(C, i^*)}{\varepsilon '} > 0ε′ε′L(C,i∗)−εL(C,i∗)​>0

A surprise devaluation increases government revenue in the period in which the devaluation takes place

Seignorage reverts to zero in period t + 1 as the exchange rate remains constant and equal to ε′\varepsilon 'ε′ from then on

Inflationary Finance of Fiscal Deficits

Next, consider a floating exchange rate regime in which the central bank targets a path for the money supply

Specifically, suppose that Mt=(1+μ)Mt−1,∀t=1,2,…M_t = (1 + \mu)M_{t-1}, \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsMt​=(1+μ)Mt−1​,∀t=1,2,…, where μ>0\mu > 0μ>0 is the growth rate of money supply

Verify that: εt+1εt=(1+μ),∀t=1,2,…\frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t} = (1 + \mu), \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsεt​εt+1​​=(1+μ),∀t=1,2,…

By PPP: Pt+1Pt=(1+μ),∀t=1,2,…\frac{P_{t+1}}{P_t} = (1 + \mu), \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsPt​Pt+1​​=(1+μ),∀t=1,2,…

  • Inflation equals the growth rate of the money supply

By interest parity: 1+it=(1+i∗)εt+1εt=(1+i∗)(1+μ),∀t=1,2,…1 + i_t = (1 + i^*)\frac{\varepsilon_{t+1}}{\varepsilon_t} = (1 + i^*)(1 + \mu), \forall t = 1, 2, \ldots1+it​=(1+i∗)εt​εt+1​​=(1+i∗)(1+μ),∀t=1,2,… (4)

  • Let i(μ)=(1+i∗)(1+μ)−1i(\mu) = (1 + i^*)(1 + \mu) - 1i(μ)=(1+i∗)(1+μ)−1 denote the solution to (4)
  • Observe i(μ)i(\mu)i(μ) is increasing in μ\muμ

From money market clearing: Mtεt=L(C,i(μ)),∀t=1,2,…\frac{M_t}{\varepsilon_t} = L(C, i(\mu)), \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsεt​Mt​​=L(C,i(μ)),∀t=1,2,…, we infer that

εt+1=Mt+1L(C,i(μ))=(1+μ)MtL(C,i(μ))=(1+μ)εt,∀t=1,2,…\varepsilon_{t+1} = \frac{M_{t+1}}{L(C, i(\mu))} = \frac{(1 + \mu)M_t}{L(C, i(\mu))} = (1 + \mu)\varepsilon_t, \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsεt+1​=L(C,i(μ))Mt+1​​=L(C,i(μ))(1+μ)Mt​​=(1+μ)εt​,∀t=1,2,…

Conclusion:

  • The nominal exchange rate grows at the same rate as money supply
  • Real money balances in equilibrium are constant and decreasing in μ\muμ

From Mt=εtL(C,i(μ)),∀t=1,2,…M_t = \varepsilon_tL(C, i(\mu)), \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsMt​=εt​L(C,i(μ)),∀t=1,2,…, we obtain:

Mt−Mt−1εt=εtL(C,i(μ))−εt−1L(C,i(μ))εt\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} = \frac{\varepsilon_tL(C, i(\mu)) - \varepsilon_{t-1}L(C, i(\mu))}{\varepsilon_t}εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=εt​εt​L(C,i(μ))−εt−1​L(C,i(μ))​

Mt−Mt−1εt=εt−εt−1εtL(C,i(μ))\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} = \frac{\varepsilon_t - \varepsilon_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t}L(C, i(\mu))εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=εt​εt​−εt−1​​L(C,i(μ))

Mt−Mt−1εt=εt−1(1+μ)−εt−1εt−1(1+μ)L(C,i(μ))\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} = \frac{\varepsilon_{t-1}(1 + \mu) - \varepsilon_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_{t-1}(1 + \mu)}L(C, i(\mu))εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=εt−1​(1+μ)εt−1​(1+μ)−εt−1​​L(C,i(μ))

Mt−Mt−1εt=μ1+μL(C,i(μ))\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} = \frac{\mu}{1 + \mu}L(C, i(\mu))εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=1+μμ​L(C,i(μ)) (inflation tax revenue)

Growing money supply at a constant rate creates seignorage revenue.

Inflationary Finance and the Laffer Curve of Inflation

Typically, inflation tax revenue as a function of µ has an “inverted U” shape.

Suppose that the government finances a constant fiscal deficit entirely through seignorage revenue

  • DEFt=DEF>0DEF_t = DEF > 0DEFt​=DEF>0 for all t
  • Btg=Bt−1gB_t^g = B_{t-1}^gBtg​=Bt−1g​ for all t (e.g. because the government reached its borrowing limit)
  • The government finances the fiscal deficit by printing money (monetization of the fiscal deficit)

Then the government budget constraint simplifies to:

DEF=Mt−Mt−1εt=μ1+μL(C,i(μ))DEF = \frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{\varepsilon_t} = \frac{\mu}{1 + \mu}L(C, i(\mu))DEF=εt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=1+μμ​L(C,i(μ))

There are 2 values of the money growth rate, μ1\mu_1μ1​ and μ2\mu_2μ2​, that generate enough seignorage revenue to finance DEFDEFDEF.

We assume DEFDEFDEF is financed by μ1\mu_1μ1​ (point A).

  • Typically, economies are on the upward-sloping part of their Laffer curve

An increase in the fiscal deficit from DEFDEFDEF to DEF′DEF'DEF′ requires increasing the money supply at a faster rate (point A').

  • This implies a higher inflation of μ′\mu'μ′ and a higher depreciation rate of μ′\mu'μ′

Deficits above DEF∗DEF^*DEF∗ cannot be solely financed by printing money

Balance of Payments (BOP) Crisis

Suppose the government pegs the nominal exchange
rate and runs fiscal deficits DEFt≥DEF>0DEF_t ≥ DEF > 0DEFt​≥DEF>0:

  • unsustainable & BOP Crisis
  • the central bank often suffers a speculative attack
    • right before the peg is abandoned
    • loses vast amounts of foreign reserves in a short period of time

BOP Crisis Model Setup:

  • Government runs a fiscal deficit of DEF>0DEF > 0DEF>0 each period
  • announces a currency peg in period 1
    • The government fixes the nominal exchange rate: εt=ε\varepsilon_t = \varepsilonεt​=ε
  • initially holds a positive stock of foreign assets: B0g>0B_0^g > 0B0g​>0
    • Think of B0gB_0^gB0g​ as foreign reserves
  • has no access to credit, i.e. faces the borrowing constraints Btg≥0,∀t=1,2,…B_t^g \geq 0, \forall t = 1, 2, \ldotsBtg​≥0,∀t=1,2,…

Technical assumptions:

  • M0=εL(C,i∗)M_0 = \varepsilon L(C, i^*)M0​=εL(C,i∗)
  • B0gB_0^gB0g​ equals (L(C,i∗)−L(C,i(μ)))(L(C, i^*) - L(C, i(\mu)))(L(C,i∗)−L(C,i(μ))) plus a multiple of DEFDEFDEF

3 phases of a BOP crisis:

  • Pre-Crisis Phase: periods t≤T−2t \leq T - 2t≤T−2
    • currency pegged and expected to be pegged in the next period
  • BOP Crisis: period T−1T - 1T−1
    • currency pegged but peg is expected to be abandoned in the next period
    • speculative attack
  • Post-Crisis Phase: periods t≥Tt \geq Tt≥T
    • currency no longer pegged
    • government ran out of foreign reserves
    • government prints money to finance its fiscal deficit

Pre-Crisis Phase

Pre-Crisis Phase: t∈{1,…,T−2}t \in \{1, \ldots, T - 2\}t∈{1,…,T−2}

The currency is pegged in the current and next period: εt=εt+1=ε\varepsilon_t = \varepsilon_{t+1} = \varepsilonεt​=εt+1​=ε

Therefore:

  • Pt=εP_t = \varepsilonPt​=ε
  • it=i∗i_t = i^*it​=i∗
  • Mt=εL(C,i∗)M_t = \varepsilon L(C, i^*)Mt​=εL(C,i∗)
  • Seignorage is Mt−Mt−1Pt=0\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{P_t} = 0Pt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=0
  • The central bank loses foreign reserves: Btg=Bt−1g−DEFB_t^g = B_{t-1}^g - DEFBtg​=Bt−1g​−DEF

Post-Crisis Phase

Post-Crisis Phase: t∈{T,T+1,…}t \in \{T, T + 1, \ldots\}t∈{T,T+1,…}

  • Bt−1g=Btg=0B_{t-1}^g = B_t^g = 0Bt−1g​=Btg​=0 (the government has no foreign reserves)
  • government prints money at rate μ\muμ to finance fiscal deficit: Mt=(1+μ)Mt−1M_t = (1 + \mu)M_{t-1}Mt​=(1+μ)Mt−1​
  • εt=(1+μ)εt−1\varepsilon_t = (1 + \mu)\varepsilon_{t-1}εt​=(1+μ)εt−1​
  • Pt=(1+μ)Pt−1P_t = (1 + \mu)P_{t-1}Pt​=(1+μ)Pt−1​
  • 1+it=(1+μ)(1+i∗)1 + i_t = (1 + \mu)(1 + i^*)1+it​=(1+μ)(1+i∗) or it=i(μ)i_t = i(\mu)it​=i(μ)
  • Mt=PtL(C,i(μ))M_t = P_tL(C, i(\mu))Mt​=Pt​L(C,i(μ))
  • seignorage Mt−Mt−1Pt=L(C,i(μ))μ1+μ\frac{M_t - M_{t-1}}{P_t} = L(C, i(\mu))\frac{\mu}{1 + \mu}Pt​Mt​−Mt−1​​=L(C,i(μ))1+μμ​
  • DEF=L(C,i(μ))μ1+μDEF = L(C, i(\mu))\frac{\mu}{1 + \mu}DEF=L(C,i(μ))1+μμ​

BOP Crisis Phase

BOP Crisis: period T−1T - 1T−1

The currency peg is in place but about to collapse: εT−1=ε<εT\varepsilon_{T-1} = \varepsilon < \varepsilon_TεT−1​=ε<εT​

How large is the depreciation between T−1T - 1T−1 and TTT?

The government budget constraint for t=Tt = Tt=T:

L(C,i(μ))(1−11+μ)=DEF=MT−MT−1εT=MTεT−MT−1εT−1εT−1εT=L(C,i(μ))−MT−1εT−1εT−1εTL(C, i(\mu))(1 - \frac{1}{1 + \mu}) = DEF = \frac{M_T - M_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_T} = \frac{M_T}{\varepsilon_T} - \frac{M_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}}\frac{\varepsilon_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_T} = L(C, i(\mu)) - \frac{M_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}}\frac{\varepsilon_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_T}L(C,i(μ))(1−1+μ1​)=DEF=εT​MT​−MT−1​​=εT​MT​​−εT−1​MT−1​​εT​εT−1​​=L(C,i(μ))−εT−1​MT−1​​εT​εT−1​​

The above implies:

L(C,i(μ))11+μ=MT−1εT−1εT−1εTL(C, i(\mu))\frac{1}{1 + \mu} = \frac{M_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}}\frac{\varepsilon_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_T}L(C,i(μ))1+μ1​=εT−1​MT−1​​εT​εT−1​​ (5)

Money market clearing in T−1T - 1T−1 implies:

MT−1εT−1=L(C,iT−1)\frac{M_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}} = L(C, i_{T-1})εT−1​MT−1​​=L(C,iT−1​)

interest parity for bonds purchased in T−1T - 1T−1 implies:

εT−1εT=1+i∗1+iT−1\frac{\varepsilon_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_T} = \frac{1+i^*}{1+i_{T-1}}εT​εT−1​​=1+iT−1​1+i∗​ (6)

Plugging these into (5) yields:

11+μ=L(C,iT−1)1+i∗1+iT−1\frac{1}{1 + \mu} = L(C, i_{T-1}) \frac{1+i^*}{1+i_{T-1}}1+μ1​=L(C,iT−1​)1+iT−1​1+i∗​ (7)

iT−1=i(μ)i_{T-1} = i(\mu)iT−1​=i(μ) solves (7) because 1+i∗1+(1/μ)=11+μ\frac{1+i^*}{1+(1/\mu)} = \frac{1}{1+\mu}1+(1/μ)1+i∗​=1+μ1​

Moreover, only iT−1=i(μ)i_{T-1} = i(\mu)iT−1​=i(μ) solves (7) because both L(C,iT−1)L(C, i_{T-1})L(C,iT−1​) and 1+i∗1+iT−1\frac{1+i^*}{1+i_{T-1}}1+iT−1​1+i∗​ are decreasing in iT−1i_{T-1}iT−1​

Thus in T−1T - 1T−1:

  • the nominal interest rate increases to its post-crisis level i(μ)i(\mu)i(μ)
  • real balances Mtεt\frac{M_t}{\varepsilon_t}εt​Mt​​ fall to their post-crisis level L(C,i(μ))L(C, i(\mu))L(C,i(μ))

Finally, iT−1=i(μ)i_{T-1} = i(\mu)iT−1​=i(μ) and (6) imply that the rate of currency depreciation between T−1T - 1T−1 & TTT is μ\muμ:

εT=(1+μ)εT−1\varepsilon_T = (1 + \mu)\varepsilon_{T-1}εT​=(1+μ)εT−1​

Seignorage equals:

MT−1−MT−2εT−1=MT−1εT−1−MT−2εT−1=L(C,i(μ))−eL(C,i∗)e\frac{M_{T-1} - M_{T-2}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}} = \frac{M_{T-1}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}} - \frac{M_{T-2}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}} = L(C, i(\mu)) - \frac{eL(C, i^*)}{e}εT−1​MT−1​−MT−2​​=εT−1​MT−1​​−εT−1​MT−2​​=L(C,i(μ))−eeL(C,i∗)​

Foreign reserves of the central bank fall by more than DEFDEFDEF:

BT−1g=BT−2g+MT−1−MT−2εT−1−DEFB_{T-1}^g = B_{T-2}^g + \frac{M_{T-1} - M_{T-2}}{\varepsilon_{T-1}} - DEFBT−1g​=BT−2g​+εT−1​MT−1​−MT−2​​−DEF

BT−1g=BT−2g+L(C,i(μ))−L(C,i∗)−DEFB_{T-1}^g = B_{T-2}^g + L(C, i(\mu)) - L(C, i^*) - DEFBT−1g​=BT−2g​+L(C,i(μ))−L(C,i∗)−DEF

BT−1g<BT−2g−DEFB_{T-1}^g < B_{T-2}^g - DEFBT−1g​<BT−2g​−DEF

Note that L(C,i(μ))−L(C,i∗)<0L(C, i(\mu)) - L(C, i^*) < 0L(C,i(μ))−L(C,i∗)<0

The Dynamics of a Balance of Payments Crisis

  • The depreciation rate and inflation are zero until T−1T - 1T−1 and jump to a permanently higher level in TTT
  • The nominal interest rate jumps one period earlier in T−1T - 1T−1 because of the anticipated depreciation in TTT
  • The increase in the interest rate induces households to reduce their real money holdings in T−1T - 1T−1
  • Nominal money demand Mtd=εtL(C,i)M^d_t = \varepsilon_tL(C, i)Mtd​=εt​L(C,i) and thus nominal money supply MtM_tMt​
    • drop in T−1T - 1T−1 as iT−1>iT−2i_{T-1} > i_{T-2}iT−1​>iT−2​ while εT−1=ε\varepsilon_{T-1} = \varepsilonεT−1​=ε
    • grow at a constant rate from TTT on (creating seignorage)
  • Foreign reserves fall by DEFDEFDEF per period until T−2T - 2T−2 and then get depleted by a final, larger drop in T−1T - 1T−1
